54.description: Best Spicy Italian sub in Chicago.The extra spicy giardiniera is really spicy and really good.The pepper jack cheese actually has a pepper jack taste.You taste every part of the sandwich in every bite.So good.

48.description: The Italian subs here are really, really good. And, a super value. Very nice and friendly staff too. Can't wait to try their other subs.

44.description: BIG fan of the italian beef and their italian sandwich on Focaccia bread! Large subs are VERY generous and prices can't be beat for the type of quality you're getting. The beef is not too thin and is delicious. Their homemade giardiniera pairs very well with the beef. The times i have gotten the beef I didnt request for a dip...i drive about 30 minutes to get home and by that time the bread has soaked up the juices so there's no need! The focaccia is great as well. Meats are fresh. Friendly service.TIP: hold your ground at the deli counter...people will cut...but karma will get them if so....

24.description: Best Italian subs in town!! I've been going there since I was a little kid and the old neighberhood feeling never goes away.

7.description: BIG fan of the italian beef and their italian sandwich on Focaccia bread! Large subs are VERY generous and prices can't be beat for the type of quality you're getting. The beef is not too thin and is delicious. Their homemade giardiniera pairs very well with the beef. The times i have gotten the beef I didnt request for a dip...i drive about 30 minutes to get home and by that time the bread has soaked up the juices so there's no need! The focaccia is great as well. Meats are fresh. Friendly service.TIP: hold your ground at the deli counter...people will cut...but karma will get them if so....

49.description: The Italian sub was a perfect blend of flavors with the hot giardiniera. My daughter was choking on her sandwich trying to eat it and say amazing at the same time!

40.description: I don't know how I'm going to get through the summer without eating Bari every weekend. Best neighborhood sub spot. Friendly atmosphere. Ridiculous prices.

53.description: OMG. I think I just found my favorite Italian beef in Chicago!!! I've tried it at Al's #1 in Wrigleville and different italian/pizzerias like Armands and Pizanos's in Wicker park to name a few. The flavor and quality of the meat is of most importance to me. Au juice and peppers are second. I find it a challenge to find a place where the beef is of good quality, flavorful, and is not too oily. Al's was way too oily and not flavorful at all. Why have all that oil if there's no flavor! lol. Others either had the beef too bland or chewy b/c it was overcooked. I got mild gardinera, pickles, and sweet peppers on mine. The au juice and combination of flavors were just right! Not too salty and did not leave an overwhelming after taste. I'm pretty sensitive to salty and processed foods so this was a pleasant surprise. Highly recommend it!!

30.description: What a coincidence that another yelper mentioned that the folks at Bari always call him "Chuck Norris". Every time I waltz into Bari the guys by the meat slicing station refer to me as "The Octopus That Was in the Sky", so fitting! That's just the thing about the soldiers of the Bari good taste armada, they have an eye for detail. They call it like it is, they know you want a mean sandwich and they hand you a raging scorpion of flavor, wiggling in a paper wrapping that will be transparent by the time you make it home, you just can't contain the flavor juices infiltrating the polluted Chicago air. Id like to move away from this place just to get rid of my asthma. That reminds me, I actually have a bumper sticker on my car that says "I came to Chicago for the Bari, stayed for the Asthma!"

46.description: What a great old school Italian grocery store. Bari has delicious subs that are large in size and affordable. This almost reminds me of a place where Tony Soprano would come for some great gabagool. I usually either get the 12 inch Italian or Meatball sub. One thing to note is their bread is flaky and a little tougher than your normal soft sub bread. I prefer it this way, but I can see how some people would not like the texture if they are used to soft bread. One word of advice is to call-in ahead of time to place your order. If you go on the weekends you could be waiting in line for 20 minutes or more compared to walking in and getting your sub right away. I haven't purchased too many grocery items since the subs are so delicious, but I will soon. Oh yeah and they deliver too! I want to go pick a sub now! Keep up the prices and the quality Bari!

1.description: I used to live in Hoboken and became rather spoiled by the Italian delis. I'm a sucker for fresh mutz and good bread. After reading the reviews on Bari, I had to give it a try to see how it stacked up compared to the East Coast competition. I got the Prosciutto and Fresh Mozzarella. On the whole, it was good, but not outstanding: the bread was crusty, but the fillings were limited (really kind of light on the mutz and the prosciutto). Although there was Italian seasoning and oil, I found the taste somewhat bland. I think balsamic would make for a nice addition here.Delivery is quick though there is a $3 charge.

55.description: What is a better lunch than a REAL Italian sandwich? Seriously, I can't think of anything else. Bari has really great quality food for an unbelievable value. I have only been to the actual store a handful of times, and usually order for delivery. Delivery can take a while, but it is always worth the wait!

9.description: I'll keep this nice and simple... Bari subs are a gem in Chicago and despite some recent price increases still an absolute bargain.You can get a delicious and authentic sub made from truly quality ingredients on freshly baked bread for the same general price as a junky chain like Jimmy John's... why would you even debate this choice?Walk to the back of the store to the butcher counter. There you will be greeted by a platoon of guys working diligently to make subs for what is often a sizeable line at lunchtime. Go for the traditional Italian first but also try to mix it up with a custom order using the Italian meats they have or try a house made sausage. Don't bother with generic stuff like turkey; Bari shines with the authentic Italian meats.When you are done stop by D'Amato's next door and grab some cookies... this is among the best lunches you can have in the city and it will cost you well under 10 bucks all in. you really can't beat it.

26.description: We've been ordering subs from them for years! Tried all their subs, but the Italian is my favorite. Call ahead to order, street parking is hard to find especially around lunch time. Service is good! One of Chicago's hidden gems!

25.description: Found this through a blog and made the trip over to try it out. Great atmosphere and quick customer service. The meat was fresh and the Italian beef was served to perfection topped off with the homemade Giardiniera. Love this place and will be stopping by again.

12.description: Again in awe of their Italian beef and Italian sub - amazing house made  hot giardiniera - they just enough to meld with the flavors.  The market has everything I'm looking for in an Italian grocer.  The bread is from Damato's next door, the best canvas for a masterpiece.  I've tried other beef in good faith, but in the end I find myself racing to Bari to get a few bites (or more) to replace the taste lingering in my mouth.

59.description: Bari is an Italian grocery where you can find a wide range of products, but when I hear about this place all I can think about it's their sandwiches. They're a combination of traditional ingredients that charms you from the first bite. Every time my mother sends me here to buy sauces and fresh pastas I end up leaving the store with a huge prosciutto and mozzarella sandwich that's totally worth the effort. Sandwiches are affordable so everyone can try one every now and then. Proof that Bari's sandwiches are so famous is the line, but I don't mind waiting 15 minutes for my sandwich because I know that no other place can make it better. The grocery also features imported cookies, dried pastas and a butcher where you can find a wide range of home-made products such as sausages, rabbit or veal. If you happen to be in Chicago, you should take your time and enjoy the best sandwich you've ever eaten at Bari.

21.description: Best meatball sandwich available! Love the pre-prepared spaghetti & meatballs too!  The Bari hot sausage is the best Italian sausage I've ever eaten!

17.description: Great food, great price, great delivery! They don't really pay attention to the notes when ordering from eat24, but the sandwiches are good as is. Will definitely keep ordering, just may have to call in the special requests such as sides of dressing, or other extra condiments.

10.description: With a killer combination of capocollo, genoa salami, mortadella, provolone, lettuce, tomato, and spicy giardiniera, Bari Foods in Chicago's West Town has perfected the sandwich, any sandwich. Go!

5.description: For a neighborhood grocer/deli, they sure do a brisk business around the lunch hour! Although it was a great spot to pick up some grub after a morning at the Shedd, parking was pretty non-existent and we had to park 3 blocks away!  Oh well, we had meatballs on the brain so we had to commit. When facing the deli counter, you order at the L side--the line kind of queues that way, there is no number system so just ask the person in front of you if they are in 'the line'. I've had the regular Italian sub here and was less than impressed.  There was just something about the bread that seemed "off".  Please don't tell me that you served me day old bread, it didn't seem as fresh as I thought Italian bread should be.  The meat?  excellent.  We went back to try the hot subs and shared the sausage sub and a meatball sub. Now I felt those were much better than the cold sub. The bread on both sandwiches was so much better. Fresh and chewy soft.  Both the meatball and sausage were flavorful, but I really liked the sausage more--the flavor was bolder and heartier. There are tons of different chips to round out your meal, a cooler of their house made sauces (yum!), cheeses, staples like pasta and olive oils, small selection of fresh veggies..lots of items packed in the small store.  Deli guys are abrupt, but the cashier ladies are always kind and chatty.  I love how they dote on my son.

3.description: The best sandwiches in the city!! My husband and daughter stumbled upon this place by accident last year, and I'm so glad they did! They got me a sandwich, and I just had to know where it came from. Bari is a small Italian grocer that carries a lot of specialty items and has a meat counter in the back. There they take orders for any cuts you like, how you like, and they custom make sandwiches, in three sizes The Italian, which my daughter loves, is said to be the best in the city. I love their tuna! The sandwiches come on french bread with lettuce, tomato, onion, and/or any other toppings you'd like. They have a variety of cheeses and if you like spicy, their Gardinera is delicious. They seem to always be busy, but they get you in and out fairly quickly, and everyone is super nice. We are definitely fans!!

35.description: We placed an order online today for a grand total of 13 subs. The instructions on the order were specific and very detailed. When I arrived back at my job, one sandwich was missing. The person whom it belonged to made a special trip to visit and her lunch was not there. Additionally, the gardiniera was missing. The instructions were that they were to be on the side for the all of the sandwiches. Instead, they were all missing. The French bread was also on the hard side so it kind of scrapped my mouth whenever I took a bite of the sandwich. Please fix this!

19.description: What a great place in a great location. Bari has a wide selection of fantastic deli foods, canned goods, Italian cookies, and my favorite giardiniera ever. They have a deli counter with a great selection of sandwiches and subs, with different specials every day. We had the Italian beef with giardiniera sauce, and it was a real bargain, at $9 for a gigantic foot long sandwich. It was served up on a wheat roll with a gigantic pile of tender, juicy, thin sliced Italian beef. BTW, you have to be sure to request the giardiniera when ordering. Maybe we just caught them on an off day, but I would have liked a little more (ok, a lot more) giardiniera on the sandwich than the 5-6 pieces of veggies we got. Overall, the sandwich was delicious, but I hope to get more giardiniera next time. Bring it on!

28.description: I cannot stay away...they know me by name.  I fall more in love with the 12" turkey with extra hot giardeniera every day.  I don't care that they increased prices a bit.  Best sandwich in the city.  And really nice long-time employees make it even better.

45.description: One of the all-time great sandwich spots in the city.  The meatball sub with atomic giardiniera alone secures Bari's permanent perch in the top five best sandwiches of Chicago. This place gets wicked busy for lunch, with a line from the deli counter to the door. Or so I've heard: my experiences are always at off hours when I can peruse the fancy imported groceries and spend my well earned money.In particular, I like their selection of soda and sparkling water, their many kinds of angel wings and ornate Italian cookies, and the homemade pasta and olive salads. Delivery to my apartment in the neighborhood is always hot and fresh!

33.description: A Grrreat sandwich. When your in the mood for a good sandwich you have to go to Bari, Cold and hot sandwiches and they are all great. Fresh Mozzarella taste great with the beef its awesome !!!!!!!!! Hats off to them all.

43.description: In my opinion, Bari unequivocally makes the best "Italian" sub in the city.  I've been coming here for years, and even though they may not know my real name, they call me "Chuck Norris" ( guess they think I look like the old boy ! ! ) Although making a sub sandwich isn't rocket science, a noteworthy version can only be the sum of the freshest and best quality ingredients.  My checklist would include the following.  The bread should have a thin, crispy crust and soft crumb.  The meats & cheeses , lettuce & tomato must be both flavorful and freshly sliced.  And last, but not least, the giardiniera needs just the right amount of crunchy & soft veggies, herbs, and olive oil.  Bari meets all these standards. ( In addition, Bari makes its own giardiniera, and sells it in jars too)   Its no wonder the small place is always packed with customers.  Service is always prompt, but at prime time, you might need to wait a few minutes.  Its a small  price to pay for a terrific sub.  From Chicago cops and office workers to Italians from Harlem/Belmont, Brideport, or Elmwood Park, Bari is what the Italian-American sub is all about. If you happen to be looking for Italian groceries, they carry an ample selection of oils, canned tomato products,pasta, canned fish, and homemade condiments.  They also have fresh meats , homemade sausages, cheeses , and a wide selection of deli meats/salads.  If you don't enjoy cooking, checkout their prepared pastas and sauces.  (Currently, there are a few parking spaces just 2-3 doors South which are for customers shopping at Bari)

2.description: This place is about as Chicago Italian as they come and they have some great stuff inside. On this visit during X-Mas week, we came for sandwiches. Wonderful, wonderful Bari sandwiches. I cannot get Italian beef sandwiches in LA, where I have lived since 2002, and so that it is what I ordered... excellent. I also bought some of their house-made giardiniera for my suitcase. I haven't tried it yet, but it looks amazing. An excellent neighborhood deli.

18.description: You just have to go here and check it out. Words can't do Bari justice. It's like being teleported back to a 1930s grocery store. The deli is amazing, get an Italian sandwich. It's huge and delicious!

41.description: Ordered food from Bari this afternoon for delivery through yelp.  After confirming my order and after an hour waiting, I got an email stating that they cancelled the order because they decided to close early.  Now how many yelp stars would you give a place that did this??  I've stopped in many times and while their subs are really good and affordable, the Sunday management team has a lot to learn about customer service....

52.description: For $8 you can get a massive, tasty, Italian sub on tomato focaccia! One of the best deals around. This is a small Italian grocer with a deli counter in the back where you can get awesome made-to-order sandwiches. No area for eating in but no big deal. They accept credit cards which is convenient. If you do happen to have a few bucks on you though, stop in D'Amatos next door for some fantastic square pizza slices (they can warm them up if you're eating in) and arancini! Anywho, I highly recommend this sandwich at Bari!

50.description: Mom and Pop shop, running at the speed of light. If you arrive at lunch/dinner, expect a line (it forms on the left aisle).This place makes & cans their own giardiniera. Just a warning, the hot really is hot. Best Italian Beef in Chicago? Check. Cops eat here? Check. The unapologetic staff corrects my attempt at Italian? Check.This is a great, local, neighborhood place, a true gem in the area.

4.description: This place is not a pretender. It's the real thing. The bread is excellent, meat slices thick, and the other toppings are fresh + the prices are decent.

6.description: Bari is a pretty good although I expected to be a bit more impressed with all the rave reviews. I ordered the Italian sub because that is what you should do.  First, it is a huge sandwich and just over $5. The meat on it was very good and fresh.  The bread I found was just okay and was too much for the sandwich and the sandwich was a bit over dressed.The staff was very friendly and helpful. We also took some deli home and a few things from the Italian market.  For a small store they have a decent selection. The deli was very, very good.  It was also pretty cheap for everything we got.

22.description: What a disappointment. My partner and I have been on a mission to try every notable Italian Beef sandwich in Chicago. We were very excited when we heard about the delicious meats and sandwiches at Bari followed up with rave reviews on Yelp!  Sounded like the Italian Beef cannot be beat! We ordered both the Italian sub, which was mentioned in several reviews, and the Italian beef.... I couldn't believe it. While eating at the counter, I was starting to think we went to the wrong Bari. The Italian Sub--meat to lettuce proportion was unfair, couldn't even taste the meat, there was so much lettuce. The bread was stale, tasteless and crumbling, which was a shame because there are Italian bakeries next door and across the street. The Italian Beef-- Bland. Nothing was going on. I didn't taste the flavors, seasoning and meat juices that make Italian beefs so amazing. We were so unhappy when we left, with nothing to speak of on our palates. We think we might've gone on an off day since we're a minority in the reviews. We will try it again on another day and definitely take some sausages home from the meat counter. That looked great!

15.description: Best Spicy Italian sub in Chicago.The extra spicy giardiniera is really spicy and really good.The pepper jack cheese actually has a pepper jack taste.You taste every part of the sandwich in every bite.So good.

57.description: Bari's Deli has been a Chicago staple for over 35 years. Great sandwiches can be delicate, gut-busting, humble or flashy. What they have in common is that they're built with love and care and great quality ingredients. This is exactly what Bari's Deli has created for several decades. If you landed here, it means you are searching for a fantastic sub sandwich in Chicago. Yeah, yeah, bada-bing bada-boom-boom, you found it so look no further, because this joint is number one when it comes to subs. We love the made-to-order deli sandwiches. Picking just one of their masterpieces at this deli shop is no easy task, since every massive mound of bread, meat, and cheese here is nothing short of a Chicago treasure. Years ago, I tried the prosciutto, sopressata comprised of fresh mozzarella, sweet roasted peppers and olive oil -- simply memorable -- fresh, chewy bread melds perfectly with the cold cuts and cheese. The savory olive spread adds an extra kick to the whole she-bang. We were astounded by the carniv-orgasmic offerings at this place when we first  came here over 10 years ago!You can try ham, salami, turkey, roast beef, mortadella with American, Swiss or provolone cheese, lettuce, tomato, onions, hot peppers, mustard, mayo, oil and vinegar, all packed on a fresh, fluffy Italian bread. The bread is simply ethereal. There are lots of solid options to choose from at this joint, which prides itself on creating sandwiches to satisfy every palette. Thick Italian bread envelops plump pieces of their meatballs, all elegantly smothered in delectable fresh mozzarella, Romano cheese and piping hot tomato sauce. Afterward, you can nap for weeks, awake refreshed (and five pounds heavier). My favorite sandwich here is their Italian sub (or Italian hero). If you want to have the gastronomical experience of a sub sandwich life time hit this place up for lunch.There is only one thing you need to know about this joint. What dat? What dat? The Italian sub is the one you want. Don't think twice! Just order it and step back. Let the man work his magic, while you marvel at the quick dance of sandwich seduction happening before your eyes. First, a long loaf of Italian bread is sliced open and fresh cured meat after cured meat thinly shaved goes directly into the sandwich. At this point, your mouth is watering as cheeses, peppers, dressing, everything, added so deftly that if you blink you might miss a step. Second, hold your wrapped sandwich tightly in your hands and try not to quiver with excitement at first bite!This mom and pop operation has been serving fantastic Italian sausage, Sub sandwiches and Italian beef for decades. I wouldn't say they have "the best" Italian beef in the city, but it is definitely worth trying (even if it is only once). This is carry-out only, so get your sandwich and get the hell out.  Bada-Bing, Bada-Boom. You're done! ;DStreet parking = 3 stars (not super difficult to find a legal spot)Sandwiches   = 5 starsService = 4 starsBreads and Circuses = 4 stars

20.description: What a great place in a great location. Bari has a wide selection of fantastic deli foods, canned goods, Italian cookies, and my favorite giardiniera ever. They have a deli counter with a great selection of sandwiches and subs, with different specials every day. We had the Italian beef with giardiniera sauce, and it was a real bargain, at $9 for a gigantic foot long sandwich. It was served up on a wheat roll with a gigantic pile of tender, juicy, thin sliced Italian beef. BTW, you have to be sure to request the giardiniera when ordering. Maybe we just caught them on an off day, but I would have liked a little more (ok, a lot more) giardiniera on the sandwich than the 5-6 pieces of veggies we got. Overall, the sandwich was delicious, but I hope to get more giardiniera next time. Bring it on!

36.description: It is impossible to find a better and more authentic Italian American grocery store sandwich than the kind served at Bari.  They also have a nice small butcher section,  though the meat isn't locally sourced.  I've gotten sandwiches here dozens of times.  Pure Chicago.

14.description: Bari you broke my heart, you broke my heart! If this was the Godfather Bari would have to go. An utter dissapointment. After reading a columnist from Serious Eats claim that Bari's might be the best beef he ever had and Thrillist list it as its #6 beef, I just had to try it...I couldnt wait, even if it wasnt the best beef Ive ever had it would be damn close.My first bite chomp chomp, swallow a bit, roll the flavors around. What the.... Roast beefy...A step above Arby's but "possibly the best beef ive ever had" really guy from Serious Eats? Is he from California or something?! No flavors were popping in my mouth, nothing dancing...Mr. Beef, those flavors are like a sassy, hot Latina taking over the dance floor in my mouth. Bari's, a middle aged white man trying to jusr stay on his feet...Where is the Oregeno? The bread was pretty darn good...But what good is it if the beef sucks...Its like a cool take home box but if you put dog turds in their I really dont want the box now...Get my point!To be honest they seem to crank out sandwiches left and right and Ive heard great things about their cold cut subs so I probably will meander back in someday. Its an old school joint that seems to have good quality meat. Therefore I know they can do better, thats why two stars.... Just stay away from their Italian Beef!

0.description: This is a small ethnic store, offering primarily Polish and Hispanic food items. The produce looked very nice. I bought some of the prettiest romaine lettuce I have ever seen and some good cilantro.The deli counter was not big, but they carried very nice products. Mom got some headcheese and I, in my eternal quest to try every variety of sausage and sandwich meat on earth, got half a pound of zywiecka sausage. They had samples to try and it was quite yummy.This is almost like an ethnic convenience store. It is great place to stop to pick up a few needed items, but not for major grocery shopping. If I am in the area again, I would not hesitate to stop in, especially for produce and deli items.

1.description: hands down the best coffee in chicago, maybe even the country.  ive been drinking this fine blend for years and tasted others all over the world, i must say the flavor along with fine aroma is just amazing!  this coffee should have a spot on everyone's bucketlist

0.description: Delicious coffee! Had an unlucky time with a bag I bought earlier but, I gave it a second chance at a local cafe and it was superb! Wonderful aroma and after taste. Not only that but these people care about every customers satisfaction and that is rarity these days.

12.description: I was referred to Affinity Optical by my insurance company, I was not sure if I even wanted to go there, I was just calling around first. But after my initial conversation I was sold, made the appointment and went the next week. They are professional, funny, so helpful and I was able to finally get a prescription that actually worked for my eyes. I feel like it was the best eye exam I ever had, the doctor took his time with me and did an awesome job the best part is he made me laugh and put me at ease.I will make Affinity Optical my go to place WHEN EVER I need to get an exam or some swanky new glasses or contacts.  They also have an amazing selection, even a whole retro section that I could not stop drooling over. Everyone is a ROCK STAR at Affinity Optical . . . and NO they did not pay me to say this . . . in fact I baked them cupcakes and a thank you card when I went to pick up my glasses. Stop by and say hello and let them know cupcake girl sent you!!! :~}

3.description: I have been going to Affinity Optical for years.  Always get great service, and attention.   I am a bit of a 'nudge' when when it comes to fitting and getting used to new glasses so it means a lot to me that they take their time and are very patient with me.  I was just there a couple months ago and got new glasses  and  I always get a spare pair.  Today my 'spares' fell off the top of my head and got smashed to bits by a car in the Jewel lot.   Went in to see the Dr. and he told me to pick out a pair and he is making my 'new spares' for FREE!!   Can't beat that!  I would recommend Affinity to anyone looking for a great eye doctor with a fun personality and generous too boot!!   Thanks Doc!!!

1.description: I have never been disappointed.  My parents were going there for years prior to me going there.  The front desk staff is super nice and the doctors are amazing!  I've called at the last minute because of a scratched cornea and they got me right in...twice.  I've been very happy with Affinity Optical since my family started going there. I highly recommend them!!!

2.description: Our family has been customers of Affinity for both examinations, eye care and glasses for at least a decade.  Each and every visit they outdo themselves; honest, polite, expedient, knowledgeable, competitive prices, quality, quality, quality.  We would never consider going elsewhere.

9.description: The Doc is great. It was the first time I have ever had someone spend so much time trying to get my prescription correct (I have some tricky eyes). And he also took the time to explain why it was difficult. I was blown away by the effort.

10.description: I love Affinity Optical. Dr. Najem is the only optometrist I trust with my eyes. He is extremely thorough and patient. I have gone to several optometrists/ophthalmologists in the past and none gave me such a thorough and professional eye exam. Dr. Najem really cares about his patients. He answers all of my annoying eye questions, which I really appreciate. Dr. Lewis is also great- very personable and professional! The office was recently remodeled and looks very upscale. The customer service is also great. I recommended Affinity Optical to many friends and all had a good experience each time they went, as well. This place is in a large strip mall area, so it is quite easy to miss, but definitely a gem.

13.description: My family has been seen by Dr. Lewis for years. She used to be the doc at the For Eyes on Peterson, in Chicago, that's where we met her. She recently left to go into practice with her brother at Affinity. (He's the other optometrist there - or maybe he owns the place). At any rate, it's a schlep for us and I still haven't made it there, but I will. My wife and son drive out there because of Dr. Lewis, whom they love. She gives a very, very thorough exam, and she is really good and nice, so I recommend it.

16.description: very good service here they do an exelent job

6.description: this place can not be beat ! super professional friendly  medical team for the eye . very  complete eye evaluation . the frames are very cool and i love the old eye glasses on display . dr. najem is very professional . will blow gabriels horn loud to all my friends and family about this eye clinic ! AAAAA +++++ ! ! !

15.description: This shop has been here for years. Exactly how many years I'm not sure. They have a lab and an eye doctor on the premises. Their prices are very reasonable. which is always a good thing. They also specialize in fitting patients for contacts. They are in the Jewel strip mall that has a bunch of stores. The lot is usually pretty full. It looks like all the stores here are doing really well.

0.description: I've been coming here all my life but decided to try LensCrafters one time which turned out to be a less then favorable experience. My experience at Affinity today reminded me of why I've always came here. Their customer service is beyond professional. The girls at the front best are very courteous and Dr William Najem is extremely patient, he worked with me until my prescription was perfect. 5 stars for the best price, professional staff and great inventory !

5.description: I've been coming to this office for a few years now and always have a good experience.  I see Dr. Barabas and he is great with contacts, he was the only one who found me a contact that wasn't tissue paper thin or a hard contact.  The contact I used to wear is no longer made, it was actually made to fit your eye not like most of the one size fits all, thin contacts of today.  I don't think I've ever waited longer than ten minutes to see the doctor.  Everyone is pleasant and professional and there is a good selection and prices of eyeglasses.  I always like to support the local businesses.

11.description: Dr. Lewis was very patient with both of my children.  One demanded more patience than the other.  I'm glad that I found this office so close to home.It was a pleasant, pain-free experience all around.  From the moment we scheduled our appointment to the moment we left the office.  Nelson is great and so is the other young girl.  Super friendly, super patient.Love 'em!

8.description: This is the only place I will go to for myself and my children. It is the perfect example of how shopping small and supporting local businesses is better than big box retailers. Both Dr. Lewis and Dr. Najem are extremely professional  and the front desk staff always make sure to stay within my budget. One word of advice-- for glasses, purchase the anti-glare option  it is definitely worth the money. The only criticism I could think of is that maybe they could have a larger selection of frames, but I always find one or two pairs that I really like. Love this place.

4.description: The doctor is awesome, very nice and gentle. I just love this optical. Some times it take lil long to get glasses but its worthit.

14.description: Great experience with the Dr. but also really wonderful front desk receptionists - best receptionists I have yet to encounter!  Having lived in and experienced Japanese customer service, this is saying something.  Both young ladies were very professional, courteous (which I would expect from receptionists anyway), but they were also kind and very thoughtful - like good southern hospitality. I was thoroughly impressed with the office!  I believe that good and happy staff members also reflect highly on the management - looking forward to the next visit :)

7.description: Last week I had an appointment for Thursday at 6pm for my daughter. I had called in and made that appointment about a week or two before.  Well, around late morning of THAT day, a guy from Affinity Optical called me.  He asked if I could come in earlier than the scheduled appointment, like 5pm.  I explained I really couldn't because I was already leaving a half hour early from work just to make the 6pm appt. I asked if that was a problem.  He told me no and that he would just have to shuffle around some appointments (huh? - mine was the last appt) And he didn't sound very reassuring, so I ask, "Are you sure/"  He replies yes.  Well, some time later, my cell phone rings again.  GUESS WHO?  Another employee from Affinity.  This time, a woman and, yup, she asks me if I can come in earlier than my 6pm  APPOINTMENT (deja vu?) The reason she tells me is because the doc's last appt before mine is 3pm and she would be just waiting until I came in. So here I am at work, ya know, that kind of place I go for 8 hours a day so my family and I can have a roof over our head, food in our tummies...I think alot of people are familiar with that..busy at work and these people keep calling me about changing my appt last minute.  Do they even know the "point" of an appointment???  I freakkkn obviously needed a 6pm appt - that's why I made it... Anyway, by this time, my annoyed meter is at maximum.  I tell her, "Just cancel the appt"  Then she says, "oh the doctor is willing to wait for  you"  I say "Noooo, Just cancel the appt and you guys leave early"...Anyway I already found a couple of places with great reviews and I will make sure those guys understand what an appointment means...

1.description: They do ok job. They don't like when you bring your own ideas and pictures to show them what do you want. There is a older lady (around 45-50 years old, short, red hair) --I think she is a shampoo person. What I don't like about her is that she comes around you when you pay, so you would tip her too.

2.description: I had my hair done here on a recommendation of a friend and love my hair. I thought everyone was very nice and the atmosphere was comfortable. If your looking for a good salon without salon attitude check out this salon.

0.description: Had my hair dyed red - and I'm obsessed with the results. Ask for Patrycja (correct spelling!), you seriously will not be disappointed!

attributes.Hair Types Specialized In: Asian Hair, Curly Hair, Perms, Extensions, Straight Perms, Coloring, Kids' Hair

58.description: This is a very fun store. They have a huge selection of cds and movies. Although they are very dedicated to the rock and metal genre as evidenced by the crazy decorations on the outside and the blaring music and band t-shirt up for sale -- they do actually care a wide variety of music. If you can take the music, it's worth a visit just for the views from the inside.

56.description: Rolling Stones!!! My earliest music mecca. Walked there the day after graduating grammar school and the played " Schools Out " by Alice Cooper for me...Spent lots of my graduation money!!!

29.description: How can you not love Rolling Stones?  This record store epitomizes the Northwest Side teenage experience.  I think the teenage, surly, too cool for school employees are kinda cute.  They're like babies!  Unfortunately as a teenager I was way too bashful to come here.  Now that I'm a grownup I enjoy browsing through their selection and finding hidden bargains.  For example, the other day I found the Ramones greatest hits for $5.99.  Score!  Only negative about Stones is their limited selection of hard to find and rare cds.  For those you should go elsewhere.

42.description: This place is great if you are looking for rare or older music, but from what I've seen lately not so much anymore.  This is not the place to buy new music.. I feel that they are over priced compared to Best Buy and Target. They do have an okay selection of all types of music and it used to be a cool place to visit. I agree with Lee C. the location does suck as there is not much parking around.

23.description: I give Rolling Stones 2 stars simply because it just dosen't offer me anything anymore.  I had stopped in a few years ago and picked up a couple dvds because I was in the area.  I could have probably saved a couple of bucks if I had gone elsewhere though.  Rolling Stones used to be the place to get cds like 10 years ago.  I could find almost everything I wanted there and I even found some good shirts.  Now I find nothing and there's plenty of other places to get dvds porn or otherwise.

47.description: Until I discovered Wax Trax, Reckless and all the old Clark Street haunts, this was my favorite record store.  Even after finding all of those places, I still stopped in at Rolling Stones.  Not so much anymore.  Long gone are the days where you'd find obscure rock.  I guess what I'm trying to say is, this place peeked in the mid 90's and has slowly slipped into a very inexpensive alternative to Best Buy.  I popped in here recently and picked up a few "back catalog" discs, but as far as new releases go, it's mainstream rock and hesher city.  They're good at what they do, but I will always long for those days in the late 80's, where it would be advisable to wear earplugs while shopping and the main area still had LP's.

8.description: Here's the metal....plus vinyl and cult DVDs .  This store brings life to the burbs. Not a huge selection but it works.  I usually find something interesting when I'm here.  Nice!!

31.description: I hate with a burning passion being stalked by the eyes of the anti- shoplifting army men but it's not the worst thing in the world. I totally want to steal those Pantera shirts that they wear ...NOT. This place is fine. I used to think it was cooler when they had more stuff that I wanted, when they had tons of odd old bootlegs.

34.description: This is the ultimate CD shop if you still use those contraptions. They've always got the newest albums and allll the old ones too. They've decorated it very cute with CD's all over the ceiling. I had a crapload of CD's stolen from me and since that day my urge to go out and buy CD's on a regular basis really died. However one of my best friends hardcore loves the store and has taken me in here many many times.You can easily spend an hour looking around if you're really in the mood to shop around. They've got a lot more obscure techno as well as other genres you won't find at say, Best Buy or wherever the kids go to buy CD's these days. If you're looking for hard to find metal music I point you in the direction of METAL HAVEN in the city. They specialize in rarity.

16.description: I have been shopping here since I was in high school and picked up my first records and cassettes. The place hasn't changed much at all. Still a great selection of import CDs you can't find any place else. The prices are decent on music but the dvd and blu rays are a bit expensive. Its cool to see they are starting to carry a wide variety of vinyl again. Over all I still find myself going back here to purchase all my music and try to keep the record stores in business in a time where downloads are the more popular thing.

13.description: Great place for music, incense and movies. I grew up in Norridge and remember when this opened in 1971 and everyone shopped here.. At least those in my age group.. And I still drive from Lombard to stock up on incense.. Always a great shopping experience. And the prices are good too!!!

11.description: Rolling Stones has incredible prices on CDs and DVDs. What are those? Well, sit down on grandad's lap  and let me tell you about the 90's! Of course, if you didn't know what a compact disc was, the thousands of shiny discs hanging from the ceiling at Rolling Stones would be a good primer. (see my "forbidden" inside store pic! Seriously, an employee practically tackled me when I took a picture and said inside pics are not allowed).Actually, the employee did pounce, but he was super apologetic and nice about it. The Security Guard on the other hand...he wasn't big on small talk, but nice enough. Still, I had a handful of CDs and DVDs in plain view, doesn't that mean I'm going to purchase them and not expect a five-finger discount? Security, seriously? What is this, Mallrats?I came to RS with a small list in my head of somewhat newer CDs by recent artists to purchase. Arcade Fire at basement prices, yes! Doves' release from a year ago? Asked the security guy because Doves didn't even have its own category card. Nope, that one was gone last year. See, Rolling Stones doesn't keep any past CDs by recent artists, just great prices on New Releases and even better prices on has beens.Rolling Stones' bread and butter is $5.99 deals on reissues of your favorite artists of the 60s-80s. They also carry an impressive selection of live concert DVDs for around $9.99. I'll certainly be back to Rolling Stones' but will leave the camera at home so I don't get tackled next time.

39.description: Maybe the last primarily CD store that exists in Chicago? And they have a lot of cheap CDs. This is the place to go get those CDs you've always meant to pick up over the years. I buy a lot of stuff I have only on vinyl here because the aveage price is $7.99. Also a lot of rare music DVDs and cheap incense. They have a decent selection of rareish 60s and 70s rock too. If you're looking for new indie rock and punk rock and metal, this is not the place. They aren't really selling underground music here. But a cool place that I am glad there is still one of left in the world.

37.description: Yikes, there's tons of crazy crap on the walls more like a TGI fridays then a music store,or an acid trip rather. A BAD acid trip mind you. The clerks seem to ALL have holier then thou attitudes which is absolutely hilarious as I've heard they all make very bare bones minimum wage and are mostly 20 somethings with nothing but a crappy music store job to their names.You gotta love the fact that when it's in the low low low numbers and freezing outside you're getting stared at like a crazy thief for wearing a thick jacket,I mean,give me a break!!!  Not really a good place to find anything underground or really very indie. Pretty plain basic typical tastes found here. Is a great place for a discount on a cd you've lost,but WHY bother giving them the money? They're all rude and irritating and the atmosphere is honestly,very seizure provoking,or at least I;d assume if I had seizures. This place blows!

0.description: I've been shopping at RS since 1982 or even before. They HAD a great selection of everything about entertainment. Great prices too. I've seen a few rock bands do in-store meet & greets here too.

38.description: Dear Stones,Hi - it's me, Chris.  Remember me?   We go way back - I remember visiting you when I was a wee young lad, remember?   You had the tapes in the glass cases that you had to ask to be opened in the front and the back was all vinyl?   Yeah.We had good times.  I loved meeting Iron Maiden, Glenn Danzig, Rob Zombie, Rob Halford, and many other bands in your store.   The old security guard - the younger guy who was an off duty cop - real friendly like, the guy who one day my buddy was shopping and asked where I was - I was on my honeymoon - then the next time I dropped in, maybe three weeks later, he came up to me and my wife, shook our hands and congratulated us on our nuptials.  Yeah, the guys like that are the reason why when my buddy got his license, that was the first place we went, and I went back - almost every week, literally, for 15 years.  I've easily spent $20,000 in your doors over the years, if you think I'm lying you haven't seen my media room.    But, we've grown apart, and honestly - it's you, not me.First - I'm so tired of being stalked around the store when I shop.  When the twin albino headbangers followed me around, it was awesome because they had no tact and because I'd pretend  I was being chased by heavy metal loving ghosts.   I remember making hilarious laps around the store, turning at random aisles just to see what they'd do, and they'd follow me at every twist and turn, I felt like Pac-Man!     Meanwhile my friends would stand by the shirts and take it in and laugh hysterically.   Plus, I'm older now, I finished college, I have a career, I can see following around a 16 year old, but I'm nearly 30 - get off my back.  It's not even the fact that I'm being watched, it's that when I look at the person staring at me - sometimes because I'm walking in their general direction - they cross their arms, puff out their chest, and attempt to stare me down.   Customer service this is not.  I assure you, the past few times I had things in my hand that I intended to buy, but I was treated with such hostility I put them back.  I'm the guy that tried handing my stack of CDs to one of your thugs (he just glared at me when I told him I wasn't going to spend my money because of his attitude)....but somehow I doubt I'm the first person to do something like that.Second - I'm not here to make accusations but some of your products just don't look right - why are so many of your CDs made in South America?   I bought a CD set from you - Beethoven symphonies, yeah that's right - Beethoven from Stones, it was $30 or so which was a solid deal for something different....I don't get why the back and front covers are pixelated when I've seen this set elsewhere with crisp graphics and why the CD graphics look so....off.    It's just strange.Third - the gigantic porn section is just too much.  Really.  And what I like is you have all those jerks staring me down when I look at CDs but your porn section goes unmanned.   What's that?  You have this new technology called cameras there?   Can't you put those by the CDs?   I can ignore a camera, not Blinky and Pinky.Fourth - your shady CDs may be cheap but your DVD prices are not even remotely competitive - your $2 selection of garbage doesn't fool me.Fifth - your snot nosed check out clerks aren't cooler than me.  I assure you.  They may be younger, but their whole get up just reeks of effort.  Effort = lame.Sixth - what's with all the rap and nu-metal?   I remember seeing (relatively) obscure stuff here, cool (legal) import singles of bands I loved, and if something new was coming out by a great band, you'd have it the day it hit the streets, if not a few days earlier.  Yeah, you have the new Disturbed, but why no Damned?   You sir are the Load era - maybe there's a hint of the greatness you used to have, but for now, you just suck.You've taken enough my money.  It's been fun - I'm done though.The thing is, you're not the only CD shop in town. Reckless has taken the torch - the staff at Reckless are infinitely cooler than me, yet they'd never acknowledge it- perhaps because they're too busy doing what appears to be work, rather than staring customers down.  They also know an insane amount about music, plus I'll bet if I gave a random IQ test to any employee (or customer, no offense to the nu-metal crowd you cater to), easily 90% would break triple digits.  I'm not sure that percentage of your staff would hit double digits.If you haven't been to Stones in years, please do yourself a favor - don't even think of returning, just keep your fond memories of that great place in Norridge and let it go.I'll never forget the good times, and believe it or not I still love you.  When you get your act together, give me a call.  Chris

51.description: I spent most of my money here as a pup.  I'd say the place's forte is metal, which is why a lot of those type of bands do their signings here when they're in town.  Seriously great selection, and not limited to rock...they've got blues, jazz, country, oldies, comedy...you name it!  I love that it's not corporate-ified, and in fact blows the big box stores out of the water when it comes to selection.

27.description: It's still a great place to buy music. But, who can forget the heyday in the 70s and 80s, when the drug paraphanalia was right there in the case and you could buy the drugs in the back. Im sad they got rid of the Christmas tree with bows they would put out every year for decorations. They were cheap and tacky, but it still meant it was the holidays. I also loved the cardboard cutouts of artists. I wanted the Mick Jagger one like no ones business.

32.description: I used to make the trip over here by bus when I was in high school.  I didn't even go to the HIP, I went here and to that store down the street from it.  I've found so many CDs that I couldn't find elsewhere, and most of the time they were CHEAP!  I mean, I'll dish out $14.99 for a CD, especially if it's one I can't find, but frequently finding them for a lot less was pretty sweet.  Also, when I used to wear nothing but band shirts (most coming from concerts), I could find some harder to find ones here.  I remember once passing up a hard to find NIN shirt (one with ERASER lyrics on it) to buy the stupid Downward Spiral one and when I came back obviously it was gone.  It's ok, because I found it on ebay eventually, but man, that was a stupid buy to pass up.  I haven't been here in awhile, so I'm not sure how the employees are, but I also found a nice mix of those that liked music and liked talking about it (and helping you find what you needed) crossed with those that wanted nothing to do with you and apparently resented their job.  Eh, so be it.  Most of my music nowadays comes from friends burning me CDs or connecting my iPod to their computers and taking music that way, but when I need something and Best Buy doesn't have it or it's ridiculously over-priced I head over.

54.description: The year was 1985- the summer before freshmen year for me.  My friend who had his license was planning a trip all the way down Irving Park Rd, from Schaumburg to Chicago.  He was headed to famous Rolling Stones Records... did I want to come with?  HELL YES.  Know what happened?  I GOT MY FIRST PUNK ROCK RECORD HERE!  Looking back I feel kinda proud to admit that the record I somehow decided to get that day was one to stand up pretty well to the test of time- none other than Throb Throb by Chicago's own, Naked Raygun.  See, I had good taste in 8th fucking grade- now go read my reviews and give me lots of usefuls, cools and funnys!So anyway Rolling Stones was like music mecca to young me- I wasn't ever gonna find any good records like that out in Schaumburg!  You still can't!  And Rolling Stones helped me memorize all the words to Rat Patrol as a first step on my way to a series of embarrassing haircuts.  For that I owe them bigtime!  Recent visits have obviously not been as exciting as that first trip, but they have had much of what I was looking for.  I think you should go check it out!

48.description: If this was 1990 , I would be giving this place 5 stars , Hell , nostalgia is tempting me to do so now. Sadly , all the stuff I'm looking for these days , are rarely there. I don't buy much current popular music , if I did , this place would also get higher marks. I still go here , after 17 years , and the prices are among the best , if not the best this side of the Internet (I loath Internet shopping , no glory of the hunt , no power of conquest!).  The last 25 Cd's I looked for here , I found 15 here , and got a pretty good deal.  All the bands that used to load the shelves in the era of big hair and spandex are getting harder to find there.  Time moves on , I guess , but for "obscure" (that hurt) artists , I suppose they have some representation , which is more than I can say for all the big boxes out there. I'm still pissed at this place for not having the first Danzig CD , but I guess I give them points for having two others.   Stones also has a decent DVD selection , theatrical and (chunka,chunka) adult. The DVD prices I'm not so thrilled about , a little high. You can also pick up some band shirts and hoodies , some new bands and some classic stuff. Check the back wall for discount Cd's , these don't suck , like other places discount CD sections. Heavy hitters like the Stones , The Who ,  Zeppelin , AC/DC , etc can be found there.     I love this place for what it was , I still shop there for what it is. It's still the price leader in the area , and a really good cross section. Hell , they will even order something for you . If you are reading this , odds are you can order it yourself. Another plus for all you teen guys ...cute rocker chicks , a staple since at least 1989, enjoy.

44.description: Another country heard from...well, actually, a different part of Chicago. I've never lived or worked anywhere near the Harlem-Irving RS (although I sometimes shop at the big mall), but when I worked downtown in the 80's there was a Rolling Stones (actually I think it was actually called Rolling Stone) records store at Washington and Wells.  The store carried a great array of all kinds of music and actually saw its busiest traffic on Thursday afternoon and all day Friday - READER TIME! So of course if you were picking up the paper you sort of felt compelled to at least look at the merchandise, and maybe even buy something you saw or order something you didn't.  For reasons unknown to me the store changed its name to "Rock Records" although it kept its logo similar to the H-I Rolling Stones and still has those cool pictures of 70s and 80s era stars in the window.  It's probably still the "go-to" music store for Loop workers.

24.description: Although it was a return to a time gone by, be very careful for any returns. We spent $50 in ten minutes and when we needed to make an exchange because the DVD would not download to our library, as we were told it would, they would not accept it because they require their receipt and my CC receipt was not acceptable. I was supposed to have read the back of their receipt to know this as they never mentioned it on the day before Christmas and THEY WOULD NOT HONOR AN EXCHANGE. There are better stores and they have better policies that don't make one feel like a thief even after giving them my money.The past is unfortunately past.

7.description: As a kid, Rolling Stones was my Disneyland. Everything about the place, from the CDs hanging from the ceiling to the listening stations and the rows of CDs to browse through captured my imagination. I hope every kid growing up in the Chicago area has a chance to visit this place and discover another world of music buying that is sadly going away in the Internet age.

49.description: Dear Rolling Stones,I remember back when we were kids. Well, actually, I was a kid, I'm not sure how old you were. You always seemed young and hip. I remember telling all my friends to stop listening to Vertical Horizon and to check out Sonic Youth. We came to you, and you provided us with all the Sonic Youth we could handle. I remember browsing your aisles and picking up some great Smashing Pumpkins bootlegs. To this day you were the only place where I could find an album by the Plasmatics.That's why I have to ask- what's happened? If there was ever a record I needed to pick up, that I knew wouldn't be at a normal music store or chain store, I knew you'd have it on your shelves. Just like Bob Dylan said, ' the times, they are a changin'. Every time I hear a new band I know I can't find at Best Buy, you look at me like you've never heard of them. I went to pick up the new Sonic Youth record but your S section was void of Kim Gordon and Thurston Moore. And I hear that you got into My Chemical Romance. Come on man, I thought you had taste. What happened?Your Concerned Friend,Gene

40.description: I hate this place with a passion, whenever im there they have 2 or more people staring you down(I ride my bike a lot and often wear a backpack as a result, which makes the stalking about ten times worse), and they don't even offer to help if you're looking for something. I can't get past the terrible service and rude staff enough to enjoy the simple pleasures of looking for new music. What i have purchased from here is fairly priced, but i prefer to shop in stores where im not treated like a criminal.

53.description: Ah, Rolling Stones records - truly a a landmark institution for many of us!  I still travel from the western burbs just to stop in and relive the days of my youth here!  Growing up in northwest Chicago and nearby Park Ridge, we used to come here religiously to hang with fellow rockers, hoping to catch the attention of one of the older and more cooler 19 yr olds that worked here.  Any new release, we'd be in our cars for a road trip; deejays made appearances here and so did bands.  It was and still is, a place that breeds non-conformity and craziness and spontaneity, because it's rock and roll.  I still love this place and take virgin friends to experience it for the first time.

30.description: Yes, RS is not the store it once was, but the modern incarnation is also not totally bad either as I catch many overstating. I'd actually agree with the common saying of it 'being an inexpensive alternative to Best Buy', with an addendum that it's NOT a place to find older CDs and/or ones from obscure bands. The security guards strangely(not sure why, as they used to seriously scare me hardcore!) don't intimidate me the way they once did, and in fact haven't given me any dirty looks the last few times I've stopped in here. I miss the vinyl selection they once had(RS, you continue to miss your opening of really making this a destination store once again, plus don't you wanna really leave a great impression on ex-FYE shoppers, once the dust settles on them scurrying from the mall), but they still have many deals on new CDs and DVDs(TV box set DVDs excluded), and the barato pron(oops, cheap porn, I was going for a cheesy bungling of Spanglish) selection can be fun to browse. They're not open till midnight anymore(boo!), but are still open till 11, and just off of the 78/80/X80 bus terminal. Finally, although I would've preferred you keeping your vinyl selection, it is better than nothing you kept your retro CD interior decor.And I'll settle the parking debate: park in the mall parking garage, and sneak out the secret food court entrance on Octavia by walking south till you get here. You can also park on the blocks to the west, but it can be very challenging to find street parking in those spaces(unless it's say, after 8-9pm), and why wouldn't you rather go with convenience, plus(if you're a sugar fiend, edited from beast since fiend is the actual word I wanted to use) a possible Cinnabon from the food court? And don't forget that the Illinois Entertainer magazine always has RS coupons!

46.description: When I was a kid, this place was heaven; it catered to all my music needs and provided me with the selection that the nearby Best Buy just couldn't give. But since I found out about Reckless Records a while back, I've cut back on going here a bit. They have pretty decent prices on new releases, and the bargain bin has some pretty good finds in it from time to time. Nowadays, whenever I try to find something really obscure, chances are that I won't be able to find it here. One thing that I've always found unnerving is the security guys standing around the store. I can't stand it when someone is watching me as I browse for music. Otherwise, this place is still pretty great for inexpensive new releases, DVDs, and the occasional artist appearance.

1.description: It's sad that, what was once a great store, has truly dipped in quality over the years. The store features a large tacky pornographic section near the front of the store while shoving the vinyl records to the back corner of the store. It leaves a real great impression for a record store. They're overpriced, and the staff will great you, but won't be bothered to ask if you need help finding anything. The only reason this store still gets 3/5 is simply due to the massive selection of CDs, but astonishing small record selection for a place that still claims they're a record shop.

55.description: I saw Cracker play a live set at Rolling Stones in 1994. The store hasn't changed a bit since. I remember picking up Nine Inch Nails' Fixed import EP from here for what had to be $20-$30 at the time, something my poseur ass was happy to shell out in the name of being bleeding edge.Rolling Stones is a really a nice escape from the megastores and iTunes-driven paradigm era. You can walk in and actually leave knowing you didn't hand your money to some far away corporate exec's step-son's girlfriend. This is your local money going to local business and being recycled to the hard working kids working there. I can't vouch for what they spend your hard-earned money on but if they have half the smarts as you do, oh local economy stimulator, they're probably investing is right back in the community.

9.description: I've been coming to this store since I could remember. My sister used to buy CD's and go to signings here all the time. I'm giving 2 stars because this used to be a 5 star record store and now when you walk in they treat you like a musically-ignorant criminal.Perhaps it's because I'm a female, or maybe the employees are just this rude, but these days they make me feel so unwelcome. I work in retail and I understand loss prevention but I was walking through the store looking for a particular new release and was followed so closely I felt uncomfortable the entire time.The next time I went in with my boyfriend to see if they carried his band's CD - which they do. We purchased the album in excitement and on the way out I spotted my keys on the floor. I walked back about 5ft to grab them and was shouted at as if I had just attempted to steal literally all of their merchandise. I said "I just dropped my keys" and they ripped the bag from my hand and told me I had to leave the CD at the counter. I was on shock. My boyfriend was in shock. It was completely insane. I haven't returned since, mostly because my keys and lanyard were in plain view on the floor and we were the only people in the store other than the 2 employees as far as I could tell.Music lovers like myself are often the outcasts/ rebels/ misfits, but this store used to feel like a safe place. Now it feels like a cold empty room shimmering with untouched CD's. In this digital age, they should welcome the customers they have. Not scare us away by shouting and judging us. Also, with the amount of new music they sell, you would think their old-timer employees would at least have SOME knowledge of their newer artists, but they haven't the past few times I entered the store. They were unhelpful and blankly stared at me. Not a good experience.This place is nothing like it used to be.

26.description: Okay  Rolling Stones.  You've been a great friend over the years, we've had some REALLY good times.  At times, you've been a downright PASSIONATE lover, and I really love you for that.Remember that time we stopped and got the new Jesus and Mary Chain before the family reunion?  You know, the one that made uncle Frank put out his cigarette on the picnic table, scowl and walk away.We've been through a lot together, good times and bad.  I just feel.... like,... maybe we've grown, and gone in DIFFERENT directions.   I still get a bit of a warm feeling when I think about the "good old days", but I think we've BOTH changed.No, please don't cry... I think it's best we part ways, and just be friends.    I've felt this way for a while, I guess i just kept coming back because of the kids.  We've brought all the kids by, and they've always been happy to see you, which made ME happy.  But, now, i guess I just realize that I'M NOT HAPPY.You know, I just wanted the instant gratification of a not-too-obscure, but not quite Best Buy release.  You had 15 copies of the Pogues new release.  just not what I was looking for. I hate to tell you this, because it's so mean, because you've really been a cool chick over the years.  (I remember back in 10th grade, you had that ratty mohawk, wore the Marillion T-shirt to CHURCH. You used to be SO cool.  But, last time I came by,  and you were "out", I have to tell you.   I CHEATED ON YOU.  With the girl you HATE.   You know, the one across the Street, the chick who thinks she's so HIP.   She wears that blue polo shirt  every day.  You know.  Best Buy.  I felt so DIRTY.  I haven't seen her since... It was just a one time thing.  But even that was more fulfilling than you've left me lately. You're still a good friend, but, you don't make me happy any more.   I think it was the 75 copies of the new Katy Perry release.  And, you don't look at me the same way.  You know, how you just kind of follow me around, thinking I might slip a CD in my backpack and "forget" to pay for it.   Ah, it used to be okay, but hey, I'm 45 now.    It's just... over.There WAS a time, (Exile on Main Street had just come out) when, yeah, maybe after a bong load in the parking lot, teen bravado would lead me to try and swipe something for the adrenaline rush (and the mistaken idea that girls would find me cool). But now, in the era of "free" downloads off the internet, how much do you really have to worry about someone putting a CD in their backpack?   I think, after all these years, you should be greeting me at the door with a warm croissant, maybe a martini...

25.description: Rolling Stones has incredible prices on CDs and DVDs. What are those? Well, sit down on grandad's lap  and let me tell you about the 90's! Of course, if you didn't know what a compact disc was, the thousands of shiny discs hanging from the ceiling at Rolling Stones would be a good primer. (see my "forbidden" inside store pic! Seriously, an employee practically tackled me when I took a picture and said inside pics are not allowed).Actually, the employee did pounce, but he was super apologetic and nice about it. The Security Guard on the other hand...he wasn't big on small talk, but nice enough. Still, I had a handful of CDs and DVDs in plain view, doesn't that mean I'm going to purchase them and not expect a five-finger discount? Security, seriously? What is this, Mallrats?I came to RS with a small list in my head of somewhat newer CDs by recent artists to purchase. Arcade Fire at basement prices, yes! Doves' release from a year ago? Asked the security guy because Doves didn't even have its own category card. Nope, that one was gone last year. See, Rolling Stones doesn't keep any past CDs by recent artists, just great prices on New Releases and even better prices on has beens.Rolling Stones' bread and butter is $5.99 deals on reissues of your favorite artists of the 60s-80s. They also carry an impressive selection of live concert DVDs for around $9.99. I'll certainly be back to Rolling Stones' but will leave the camera at home so I don't get tackled next time.

12.description: Rolling Stones at long last sells vinyl again... and some new as well as classic and classic/obscure rereleases.Look, today's records cost from $15 to $30 but the vinyl is different: BETTER and you have a fresh disc. Buy them here and/or down the street at BEYOND THE LIMIT. If I were 17 and loaded with cash, this would be heaven. Instead, it is where I whip out my credit card and indulge. There is still way too much DVD going on. In the recent past, porn was king here; not teen friendly. Now, the return to records is healthy. Anywhere in Europe, reocrds never went away; thank God they're back HERE and I feel great buying it again. Beatles fans, the newer vinyl versions are far better thsn your 1969 lp. Try and hear!

59.description: If you don't like rock and roll, don't go into this store.  That said, if you do love it and you don't already know about this legendary store, let me fill you in.  A huge selection of rock and roll cds,t shirts and gift items.  This place is also famous for having in store appearaces from some of the biggest names in rock and metal.

21.description: Rolling Stones used to be a place of childhood wonder. I'd gaze at the cardboard cutouts on the roof and huge posters in the windows from the backseat of my parents' car as we drove to my grandparents' house. So it's sad that years later the only wonder left is when I'm thinking, how the heck does this store stay in business?Rolling Stones gets more wrong than right. From the archaic way they display their band shirts to an analog inventory, none of it's cute or charming. And while it may be ironic to say that a store specializing in CD sales needs to get with the times, GET WITH THE DAMN TIMES.There is something seriously wrong when the nearby Best Buy offers more of a variety in music than a record store. I want to love Rolling Stones, but every time I walk in I come away empty-handed. It's not as though I'm looking for some obscure foreign death metal album either. They didn't have Matt & Kim or Slash.I'd say, hey, at least they offer porn, but then they put that display right next to teenage cashiers. Who the fuck would buy porn in front of the judgmental eyes of a child?Several key improvements could upgrade this store back to respectable levels. They're open till midnight. They have that going for them. Well ... that might be the only thing they have going for them.

17.description: Rolling Stones isn't what it used to be, which is both good and bad. No longer is this a strictly metal head/rock and roll store but has several genres which is great. What annoys me though (what may seem really minor) is they have "New release" tabs for albums that have been out for years, and no they are not remasters. I seen a Smash Mouth album as a new release and it just irked me a bit. Also, they no longer carry nostalgic apparrel such as old school wrestling shirts or 80s/90s references which were always cool. The Blu Ray section is really up to date and I actually saw several copies of Anchor-Man...which I haven't been able to find anywhere! The staff is friendly. They need to remove the video game section as it's really a waste of space.

10.description: Oh how I loved this place in the 80s when I was in high school.   I recently visited and got a few CDs for a good price.  They always have a couple petulant teens working the register but that is the stores vibe.

5.description: Grew up at this place.  It is sacred, it's the best.  I pray it stays open forever!  They have hard to find music and a huge selection.

3.description: In today's world, Rolling Stones in Norridge is kind of sad. No one really wants to buy just (or mostly) CDs anymore. Unfortunately, they decided to leave an emphasis on vinyl by the side of the road a while ago, and although that might have made sense in 1995, Rolling Stones in 2015 is now behind the times because of doing so. Yes, they do have some new LPs stashed away in the back, but the selection is more limited than it looks. Like some of the other "baby boomer strongholds from earlier times," for instance Val's Halla in Oak Park or Beverly Records in Chicago, there's a portion of us record collectors above the age of 35 who want to give these places the benefit of history in current times--"oh they just need to catch up or change some things a little, and they have so much history, so...". But the fact is, they've had years to do so now, and they still haven't.Rows of cds, with a little vinyl in the back, was cool in 2005, or maybe even 2010. In 2015, not so much. Sorry guys, but you just aren't keeping up the way your reputation from previous times suggests you should or would. Hence the 3 star rating...

35.description: I spent so many angsty teen years doing what us pissed off, anti-establishment, pseudo-anarchist, parent hating kids do: going to the HIP to eat at the Great Steak & Potato, but most of all, going to Rolling Stones. Yeah dude, time to rawk my sawks awf \m/! Sorry.All seriousness aside, this place does bring back memories. The strong aroma of incense soon as you walk through the door, employees that think they're "too cool for school", aisles upon aisles of CD's, the listening stations, and of course grabbing The Onion before you walk out the door. Prices have always been reasonable. Much better than music stores in the mall. Granted, I don't buy CD's anymore since getting the interweb at home, thus I haven't purchased anything here in a LONG time. But by browsing other reviews, there isn't any indication their prices have gone up. In conclusion, I've definitely grown out of this place. But I give it 5 stars for what it was: A place of happiness during a time when I hated everything! Rawr! \m/ (o _o) \m/

19.description: I spent so many angsty teen years doing what us pissed off, anti-establishment, pseudo-anarchist, parent hating kids do: going to the HIP to eat at the Great Steak & Potato, but most of all, going to Rolling Stones. Yeah dude, time to rawk my sawks awf \m/! Sorry.All seriousness aside, this place does bring back memories. The strong aroma of incense soon as you walk through the door, employees that think they're "too cool for school", aisles upon aisles of CD's, the listening stations, and of course grabbing The Onion before you walk out the door. Prices have always been reasonable. Much better than music stores in the mall. Granted, I don't buy CD's anymore since getting the interweb at home, thus I haven't purchased anything here in a LONG time. But by browsing other reviews, there isn't any indication their prices have gone up. In conclusion, I've definitely grown out of this place. But I give it 5 stars for what it was: A place of happiness during a time when I hated everything! Rawr! \m/ (o _o) \m/

28.description: I certainly shopped here a lot when I was 14. But times have since changed. They still have artists doing CD signings and security that watches your every move. Because you know, you want to go to jail for stealing a damn CD!I dont like feeling like a criminal when I shop. and I dont like when cashiers are cocky for no reason.They get an extra star for the ~high school memories.

45.description: Was once great. Once had real music. It had all the obscure rock and indie one could imagine. Now it is a mainstream filth hole. The security is super close at all times. For 35 min a guy followed me like i didnt know he was security. I have stopped going here. It is an institution in chicago music. But the shit they play in there now sucks and its all mainstream

33.description: I love this place. The prices are cheap, they have a great selection and a decent size listening station. I make trips to the HIP just to buy CDs here. Most popular titles $9.99 to $11.99..which is great when usually Target or Best Buy (across the street) have them for $13.99 or more. When I want to buy a CD this is the first place I go

43.description: I hate the location of this store!  I also hate the fact that there's always an employee or two mulling around in the back.  Yes, I know they're there to catch the teenagers stealing, but it always makes me feel weird.  Although the music selection is spotty, there's always a lot of good bargains on CD's.  Check out the back wall, which is filled with CD's that are between 5 and 10 dollars.   Besides copy after copy of new albums by current groups, there's also some interesting stuff that you don't see at many music stores.  Theatre of Hate?  Adam and the Ants imports?  The first album from Ultravox!?

2.description: As a follow up I was sent a reply to my 1st review where they say they are sorry but they do still have a no Returns policy on defective Vinyl... Huh?  So if I buy a record that is sealed up and walk out the front door and get to my car and open the record and it's all scratched or dinged like mine was I'm stuck with it.  That's a bull carp policy.  I did nothing wrong.  Other than buying a product from Rolling Stone that apparently doesn't have to follow the normal commercial laws of the U.S.  And you wonder why you are almost going out of business.  It boggles the mind.  You would think you would want a happy customer.  If you had taken that One defective record back I would have bought at least 20 more records from you since Christmas.  I'll shop at a decent store that values repeat customers and wants my money.

18.description: I am glad this place still stays open amidst everyone getting their music off the internet now.It's definitely a trippy place when you walk in. The smell of incense is intoxicating, the dimmed lights and the cds hanging from the wall give it a fun atmosphere to shop for music in. They have a lot of band t-shirts that were a staple of mine in the tween and teen years. You come here to find CDs though. I still like to buy them, and can normally get some cheap ones for under $10. I like to go through to remember bands and songs that used to be popular.  Parking is bad around here, but have patience.

41.description: Not always the best price, but a great place to pick up metal cd's that can be hard to find elsewhere. They have a good selection of imports/singles as well. Their music-dvd selection is oustanding. Well worth checking out.

52.description: I have always loved this place!  I loved how you could easily listen to new stuff right up front!  Great prices and I loved how money went to ONE owner instead of a big chain!  Only reason I have 4 stars instead of 5 is that parking sometimes is difficult.  Yes you can park by the HIP but not always the most convenient!  But what a great place!

50.description: On the northwest corner of Irving, Forest Preserve and Octavia is a landmark music store that stood out on that intersection till the towering HIP parking garage and Target store overshadowed it in recent years.For fans of independent music stores, this is like a model of success.
