For rock fans, this is a shrine for worshipping your guitar gods. I shopped here since I was 16 and still stop in from time to time.It's amazing how this place has survived, beating out the surrounding competition over the decades: Musicland in the 80s, mall music stores, and now fighting off Target and Best Buy across the street, as well as numerous online alternatives like Amazon.Part of it is the selection. The place is well-organized and quick to navigate, for easy locating of bands and genres. There's a separate DVD section with videos you will find nowhere else. They do a good job of catering to niche markets without you needing a special order necessarily.The exterior walls of the store and the display on its roof are its greatest advertisements - larger than life caricatures of past and present pop stars: The Rolling Stones, The Beatles, and among the legends of the past like Bowie, Michael Jackson, Led Zeppelin, Jim Morrison. I still remember their cutouts displayed along the many windows surrounding the store. Inside the store, CD's hang from the ceiling very densely, as far as the eye can see. While the stereotypical Rolling Stone shopper might be a heavy metal or punk type, which is an image it has upheld since I started shopping here over 20 years ago, they have everything from current pop hits to oldies to Yo-Yo Ma, reggae, or even country. Some rare imports or even bootlegs occasionally appear alongside regular releases, which is why it pays to check out your favorite artist's CD row every time you come. The DVD's consist of movie classics, TV shows, music videos, rare B-movies and even the naughty girls in lingerie flicks.There's also a good selection of the usual black T-shirts near the front as well.The back wall carries the best bargains in the store for current releases, in addition to the close-out discountbins near the front. By the exit, you can find a stack of Chicago Readers and other independent publications, promotional concert flyers, and even an occasional "looking for drummer" posting on the wall. In the world of groomed and manicured big box or retail chains, you would never see this.The cashiers, though they are often pierced, tattooed, or downright scary-looking gothic types are also quick, efficient and don't make snide remarks about why you are buying something that does not appeal to their own taste.I'd feel just as comfortable bringing up a Rage Against the Machine CD as I would "Lawrence Welk's Champagne Music" boxed set to the checkout... Which is why I will keep coming back to this place.

4.description: I've been going to this place for a long time. They used to be really awesome. Have band signings in the store, the used to carry rare imports etc. Now (at least to me) it's slipped a little. Still a great store but they don't carry the rare stuff and to my knowledge, they don't so the signings anymore. I mean it's somewhat nit picking but that's what made that store great to me. Oh well. I'll still shop there when I'm in the neighborhood. It's just kind of not the same.

6.description: I decided to take another walk down memory lane today, beendoing a lot of that lately!God, I still love Rolling Stones, even though I'm not that teenageranymore who stood in line for hours for autograph signings, or camein here with my friends and spent literally hours.And, yes, granted some things have changed, they still have CD'S,and quite a good assortment of them.Vinyl Records for those of us that remember, T- Shirts with bandsof your choice and lots of DVD's/Blu-Rays.And.. most of the DVD's I saw were for the "Mature Audience" if youget my drift, lots of adult Movies here!But, I can't help but still love the flashy neon colored signs and thegreat music you hear as you enter this place..So, yes, I have been coming here since the early 70's, and I'd liketo think that I am a bit older and wiser..But.. nothings ever gonna change my love for this place..Hope it stays forever..:)

22.description: I'm giving them an extra star for old-time's sake, for when back in the mid-90s, they had their incredible coupons in Illinois Entertainer where you could buy an unlimited number of albums priced up to $14.99 for only $5.99 each. I would make the 15 mile round trip down Irving Park Road on my bike and come back with my backpack bulging. But even way back in 1999, their inventory started getting reduced, and I had trouble finding indie bands they used to carry. Then the coupons stopped, which is understandable. It was too good to last. However, when demand drops off, shouldn't prices also? That's how it usually works, in everything but the damn music biz. Since their sister store Rock Records withered and died, I'm thinking I'll stop by for old time's sake.

15.description: I've made trips here for years now with my music buff friends. Its really an oasis of good taste and interesting selection. I am a big fan of their t-shirt and hoodie selection, decor, and bizarre DVD selection. Its truly a testament to their originality that they still stand after all the other major music retailers have bitten the dust. I saw people complain of a lack of certain mainstream CDs... well I have to say I am refreshed to see them not have "No Doubt" CDs filling their aisles. Look for the aggregious amount of CDs hanging from the ceiling, the hippie shop nearby, and the hum of guidos speeding their IROCs up and down nearby Harlem Ave.

57.description: If you aren't into rock, don't go there, unless you're looking for movies.  The store is great from the inside and outside.  Thousands of CDs are glued to the ceiling.  I've spent a lot of time trying to find a disc I own up there.  I did find one: Bloody Kisses by Type O Negative.Rock happens to be your thing?  You won't be disappointed.  Rolling Stones has lots of large and small rock and metal bands.  Want some weird bootleg or import from Metallica? They've got it.I have yet to mention my favorite part of the store: prices.  Last time I went to Rolling Stones, I left with 6 discs for under $70 after tax.  None of my discs were more than $9.99.  I don't know how they do it.

20.description: Why did I go here? On a friday night, my friend and I were the only customers in the store under the age of 40. While, maybe 15 years ago, this store would have been an awesome place to spend a few hours in, even cd stores back then had used cd's you could buy for cheap. Here's what this store has: -Kinda cool ceiling/cd disco looking thing going on.                                            -Live performance/concert DVD's                                            -Late hoursHere's what they DON'T have: -Records (Seriously?)                                                 -Posters                                                 -Used CD's                                                 -Headphones that aren't all broken for their listening                                                    stations! (Like 5 of their listening stations didn't work                                                   due to broken headphones)                                              This place must either be a front for some sort of underground operation, OR they are waiting for SOPA to pass and planning on banking on the newly rediscovered interest in cd's(?) Who knows. But I won't be going back.

36.description: real quickly, now. this place has cheap CDs ($9-12) up the wazoo. a good film selection too, even including a subsection for Criterion Collection DVDs. and if you're into it, they have a lot of adult films, as well. woo!i've been coming here for years and i pray to God that they don't get run out of business. this place is my source for cheap CDs both new and old. my main complaint is that the selection is not as broad as i'd like. but, hey, you're really here for cheap records so it's all good.

14.description: Rolling Stones Records aren't what they used to be, largely because the world isn't what it used to be.  I started coming here in the mid-90s when I started high school, and it was one of my first forays into that elusive subculture of rock & roll.  I was rubbing shoulders with dudes in black leather jackets, spiked collars, and eye makeup.  The devil's music blared through the speakers.  The dizzying sights of thousands of CDs reflecting colorful neon lights, framed gold and platinum albums, and rock memorabilia overwhelmed my senses.  I can't forget the aroma of marijuana incense wafting throughout the store.  Often, rock bands on tour would stop here for autograph sessions.  The lines went out the door and down the block.  Rolling Stones Records was THE hub for all things rock related in the area.  It was like the dark spot on the Norridge map.  Squeaky clean, squeaky clean, squeaky clean, wait - oh yeah, THAT place.  It was crawling with scoundrels, punkers, metal heads, posers, and freaks.  Even the roof of the building was famous - huge wooden cutouts of rock stars such as Ozzy Osbourne and Micheal Jackson beckoned to passerby. Fast-forward to 2013.  The digital age, the era of instant gratification, and lean times, generally speaking, in terms of the economy.  There stands Rolling Stones Records, a shell of what it once was.  It seems sad from the outside.  Without much upkeep or maintenance, it seems to have been forgotten.  The roof, once lovingly stocked with all the sneering characters parents loved to hate, is now mostly barren, save for one half of what was once Carlos Santana.  The band posters in the windows suggest this place now caters mostly to older rockers who still buy CDs.  The bands have stopped coming, lines no longer weave around barricades.  Inside, a surprisingly large portion of the store is dedicated to porno DVDs.  Classy.  The CD section is limited to classics and top-sellers.  You probably won't find KMFDM or 311 but you're sure to find black Sabbath's classics alongside Katy Perry.  One thing that has not changed whatsoever are the looks the security guys give you as you flip your way through the selection of CDs.  Be prepared to be given the stink eye from the moment you open the door and pass the loyal Victor Records dog sitting near the entrance.  For the sake of sentimentality, I hope this place sticks around.  I hope it can learn to find more ways to attract younger people, because at this rate it is destined to burn out as 80s rockers age and their nostalgia begin to wane.  For me, it will stand as a memory of my wild high school years - God knows how much money I have spent here.  However, I now buy my music online and use an iPod so that I don't have to lug all those CDs all over the place.  Nothing gets scratched, and frankly, I don't care about album art, nor do most people anymore.  Maybe the new hipster generation will find reasons to support this place.  Vinyl is big now, perhaps CDs will follow.  Whatever the case, though this place to me exists only as memories, I hope it can stick around.  Because if it doesn't, then, I guess it becomes a Starbucks or something.

58.description: Hey guys!! You don't October fest to go and just have a Stein !! This place has amazing comfort food too!! The new outdoor patio is super comfortable and the beer is always flowing I defiantly say check this place out. It is defiantly a great experience every time!!

56.description: I love this place.  I went there on a Friday night j7st to blow off some steam.  What a great idea!  A liter of beer and some German sausage hit the  spot.  The band was playing classic German oompa band music.  All in all a great experience

29.description: Edelweiss was great.  We went for a late lunch this Saturday.  The jagerschnitzel was tender with a savory hunter sauce on top, spaetzle, red cabbage were good as well.  For dessert my wife and I split one of the best slices of German chocolate cake.  I dare say on par with my dads, from scratch.The star of the afternoon was our server Nadia who gave us great service. She had a smile throughout the meal.  Although being busy with other service she slowed down enough to make us feel cared for.

42.description: Best German restaurant in Chicago! Last night I had the 3 lb. roasted pork shank, yes 3 lbs! It was crispy and delicious. It came with 3 sides, so I got the red cabbage, German potatoes and bread dumplings. It was a crazy amount of food. My wife had the Wiener schnitzel with bread dumplings and red cabbage; it was perfectly cooked, tender and crispy. The dinner also came with the choice of soup or salad and a bread basket. The soups were liver dumpling and cream of carrot. We had salads which were good. The beers on tap were what you would expect at a nice German restaurant with sizes ranging from a 12 oz. tap to a boot to pass around.The atmosphere is festive with lots of fun decorations and there was an accordion player singing. I noticed quite a few tables were celebrating a birthday. They have a small parking lot but it was full when we arrived at 5:15pm on a Saturday night. They have another lot, but it was easier for us to park on Irving Park across the street from the restaurant.We had food to take home - they gave us styrofoam containers which I know is typical for most restaurants but it would be nice to see a more eco-friendly container. I guess I could try to remember to bring my own.

23.description: 1st timer and we had a blast. Very quaint restaurant. Good food but I am not German so I could not say if it was authentic. The service was superb. We went with a group of 17. They were accommodating. Gave us a large room that seemed to be by our selves. Service was timely.Pros: fun atmosphere, fun music, live band many nights, German food, huge meals, the sampler could feed 5 people,Cons: a bit pricey, the front was very much a bar and you have to walk through to get to the restaurant.

47.description: I have been meaning to get here for a couple years and finally did with a couple friends. Classic old school German. Great selection of German brew and food. Was with a friend who speaks German, a definite bonus! I ordered the schnitzel with red cabbage and something else I don't recall-spaetzel? It also came with cup of soul. Any way, portion side was good and everything was delicious. The waitress, an Irish woman, was super friendly and attentive. She actually spent some time talking with us about life and family. Very enjoyable and personable. Can't wait to get back!

8.description: This place was great. Some amazing food, beer and liquors! The Edelweiss Dunkl beer is incredible. The edelweiss plater was a good variety and the potato pancakes were delicious.After enjoying my barrel sized mug of beer and the blackhaus (blackberry flavored) liquor I slept like a baby! Unfortunately we ate (and drank) so much we did not have room for desert.The service was friendly and our server did a fantastic job.

31.description: We were here celebrating the life of a dear friend after the memorial service.  Food was fresh, service was excellent,  all at an awesome value.

34.description: Highly authentic - feels like we're in Bavaria. Welcoming service and very festive. New family Christmas tradition!

16.description: Go West. This restaurant has a comfortable Old World, Black Forrest dining room next to the wood paneled bar. Service was friendly and pretty fast for lunch. It's Oktoberfest & the waitress recommended Dab beer. I know nothing about beer and I liked this one. I'm sure there are better beers and there are wurst.I ordered the vegetarian platter--I know that's nuts at a German restaurant but (a) it's interesting that they offer one and (b) this way you get try all their side dishes in one swoop. Fried spatzle were tasty, red cabbage was sweet and sour, and the homemade potato pancakes were just terrific.  Plus there was more--a roasted tomato, sauteed mixed vegetables, good dark bread, and a house salad. I didn't have room for dessert. All in all, not cutting edge, but a really good choice if you're in the neighborhood (which is unlikely for most).

13.description: Excellent authentic food, great staff, warm atmosphere. I will be back.Recommend the Schweinbraten. Gravy was to die for....OMG!  So good.

11.description: Delicious food. Very attentive staff. They dressed the part. I ordered the potato pancakes and red cabbage. I also ordered the spätzle ... Amazing. This place is 30 minutes from my house but definitely worth the trip. I will be back

39.description: Came to celebrate Oktoberfest. Extremely disappointed in the whole experience. The positions were a third of the size that they are regularly. Really enjoyed the place before but I won't be returning for a long time.

37.description: If you were looking for great German food and great service I would suggest this place.My wife had the pork roast and I had a Reuben both were delicious and I also had a great presentation we also had the Apple strudel for dessert with rhe ice cream fabulous

0.description: Had the pleasure of coming here during Christmas time, it's so beautiful with all the decorations. Make a point to get in during the holidays, you will not regret it! Cleary took a while to get my review up.. The atmosphere from the time you walk in is pleasantly  inviting. The staff are all very friendly and extremely helpful. The food and beer are excellent, you will need several visits because of all the options. My husband had the Edelweiss Platter, he loved it! This is a wonderful option if you want to try many things. I had the Shepard's Pie, magnificent! It was traditional and ever so delicious. My new favorite beer was the Köstritzer Black Lager. I now only want this beer! Hubby tried Spaten Premium Lager, he greatly enjoyed it.

38.description: Whatever they do differently during Octoberfest they need to do all the time. It is the Edelweiss I remember. Food was a lot better this time. Had prime rib and was not disappointed. The red cabbage and spaetzle was good as well. Potato pancakes tasted like they were back on track. Enjoyed the festivity the band brings, but next time I will try not to sit right in front of it.

51.description: After a long day at a conference where we were busy with behind the scenes kind of setting up and taking down, some friends and I wanted a good sit down meal so one couple suggested Eidelweiss.  I was rather happy as I had never been to this restaurant before and its been years since I've had authentic German cuisine.Wow what a place...from the general atmosphere to the food itself, its quite the experience.  You walk in and theres the bar area but then get seated in the general dining area....when we were there, they had oompa music going on which really added to the ambiance of the place.  As there were 9 of us, there was a little confusion getting the table set up but we were eventually seated.After awhile our drink orders were taken and a little later, they took our orders.  It was hard to decide what to get as everything sounded good, but then settled on the Schnitzel platter which came with the choice of soup or salad (I chose the vegetable soup).The food itself...what more can I say....my schnitzel platter came with three different kinds of schnitzel, german potatoes, and red cabbage...wow what a feast....for some they took part of it home.  Very generous portions and it was tasty.  One person did opt for dessert and she got the apple streudel which looked very tasty.All in all this was a great way to end a long and busy day among good friends.One thing to note...parking in the area can be a challenge.  They do have a small lot at the restaurant but otherwise you would have to find it along Harlem Avenue....if you feel like walking, there is an overflow lot about a 1/2 block away that is available in the evenings and weekends.

27.description: One of best German meals I ever had!  Especially the mushroom soup, weiner schnitzel, sausage, roast beef and mashed potatoes! 'Nuff said!

32.description: Short version:  customer service - terrible!Food - greasy, not as described on the menu, not cooked properly. Paid $75 for 2 entrees, 2 soups, .5L beer. Detailed version:We came in, went to the "wait to be seated sign". 5min later the bartender saw no one was coming so she seated us. Ordered the trout and the server asked if i'd like soup or salad. Asked where it was on the menu, she pointed to soup and salad, and i ordered the gulash. The gulash was really good. I can't complain. The trout was ok-ish. The julienne vegetableS was a vegetable, and that was cucumber. Soggy. On top of sweet sour kraut (not in the menu description). And a side of 2 fried potato dumplings (no salt).  Our check was $75 because our waitress charged us for the soups, although it said on the menu that soup or salad is included with any entree, but she said that applies only for the soup of the day, which wasn't even on the menu and she didn't mention it!!!!  All in all... Not going back! PS: my husbands food wasn't cooked all the way...

54.description: Honestly, only time I come in here is for the fish fry and it's amazing.

48.description: as this place is quite a distance from me, I looked forward to another visit recently but was very disappointed,.   We were the only ones in the place at 5pm on a week night so that should have been the clue.  Without going into each aspect of our experience, let me just say we won't be back!  The second star is in hope they make a comeback.

44.description: This may be my favorite German restaurant in the Chicagoland area. We frequently can be found sitting at at bar, whiling away lazy Sunday afternoons.  If Anthony is working the bar, you're in good hands.  The bar menu has great options, and the restaurant menu is even better.  If you're not sure what you want, the Edelweiss sampler plater is a great option. While I love the bar, the beer garden is a nice warm weather option, and do not miss the cute as a button dining room.  Live German music on weekends and many holidays.

24.description: The food, service and beer here are outstanding. The atmosphere is great also. We sat outside in the beer garden on a pleasant afternoon. I had the house platter and a couple of beers. Left fat and happy wanting to return soon.

7.description: So many choices for fun German fare in Chicago!The space is huge and there's a beautiful beergarden!We shared potato pancakes, which were not overwhelmingly huge and some of the best flavored pancakes that I've had.  I had the duck, and my husband had weiner schnitzel.  Both very good.  The band was Alpine Thunder, not quite as fun as the Brauhaus band, but still fun.Clientele is more "blue collar" than in Lincoln Square.  It's a fun, friendly hang out!

49.description: Came here last night for the first time and I have no complaints. The two things that stood out to me were the size of the portions and the friendly and personable wait staff. This place has a large dining room and a pretty big bar too. I got the pork schinitzel, which came with some very tasty dumplings and I also ordered a cup of the liver dumpling soup, which marked the spot. Prices vary depending on the entree you order.

40.description: Go West. This restaurant has a comfortable Old World, Black Forrest dining room next to the wood paneled bar. Service was friendly and pretty fast for lunch. It's Oktoberfest & the waitress recommended Dab beer. I know nothing about beer and I liked this one. I'm sure there are better beers and there are wurst.I ordered the vegetarian platter--I know that's nuts at a German restaurant but (a) it's interesting that they offer one and (b) this way you get try all their side dishes in one swoop. Fried spatzle were tasty, red cabbage was sweet and sour, and the homemade potato pancakes were just terrific.  Plus there was more--a roasted tomato, sauteed mixed vegetables, good dark bread, and a house salad. I didn't have room for dessert. All in all, not cutting edge, but a really good choice if you're in the neighborhood (which is unlikely for most).

53.description: Whats not to love about Edelweiss? Got a new job, and figured what better place to celebrate than at a German restaurant with good, big beers. I've lived in the area for a while, but foolishly never came here. We ate in the dining room, but the bar area looks pretty decent for watching a game.   With German music playing in the background, I noticed the interior was dated, but then again isn't most of Germany? The decor is tasteful and fits with the theme. I saw a stage for a band, but unfortunately we came on a Wednesday, and I'm guessing they're only there on the weekends. The waitstaff was extremely pleasant and very attentive to anything we needed. We were a little hesitant about bringing our 3 year old, but everyone was very nice (especially Carlos), and provided her with a kids menu and crayons. Last, but not least the main attraction- beer and food. Like many other German restaurants, they offer a variety of beers and in different sizes. We started with the pretzel and with cheese drizzled all over the top of it, I can easily say it's one of the best I've had. The pork schnitzel was breaded and cooked perfectly, as were the German potatoes and bread dumplings. The potato pancakes were the only part of the meal that seemed average...but how fancy or amazing can a potato pancake really get? Whether you're bringing the family for dinner, or sitting at the bar to watch the game with a beer and pretzel, I highly recommend checking out Edelweiss. My return visit will definitely be on a night when there's live music.

30.description: Overpriced, overall food quality is about a 7/10. If the meals were 5 $ cheeper it'd be a nice feed but they are not.

46.description: Hidden gem! Love this restaurant. Traditional German food and atmosphere with live German music on some nights. My favorite is the pork schnitzel and spatzle. Also great beer!! Their prices are reasonable as well. Can't wait to go back! Oh and they give you a little apple schnapps shot after your meal, so good!

1.description: Six years since I updated my review. We had another great meal here again today. I had another glass of gluhwein. YUM! This time I had the herring appetizer and sauerbraten. Everything was wonderful. This remains one of my favorite German restaurants. During the holiday season it is really festive with white lights all over. My only gripe, the bathrooms are not easy for disabled people to navigate.

55.description: Was here recently for a family party. Disclaimer: My family is German, so I have high standards when it comes to German food. The food was ok, but not great. Some strange takes on German dishes, for sure.  If it were just for the food, I'd probably give them 3 stars- it tasted pretty good, but nothing special.But when you take the rudeness of the staff into consideration, one star all the way. Now, I'm a friendly person and am always very polite and courteous to servers, etc- I know it's a tough job. So I was surprised, when I was walking out,when I overheard the hostess making some nasty comment about me and I looked back to see her glaring at me- um what?!?! Totally rude and uncalled for to be making mean comments about customers- there is no excuse for that, especially when I just walked by and said goodbye and thank you! If I want to be insulted, I'm at least not going to pay for over-priced mediocre food, I could get someone to be rude to me for free! Mirabelle is way better and worth driving just a bit further. No way I'd come back here after that treatment.

9.description: We went in on a Monday night - most other German restaurants were closed. The first thing I noticed was the prices! They were almost double of most of the other German restaurants. The decor was very cute - authentic / service was very good. The food was good but not great and the cost for 5 for dinner with a beer each was over $200. The pretzel we had as an appetizer was very good.

26.description: This place has amazing food and reasonably priced. The bar tender Anthony was very friendly and a master at his craft. Would recommend anyone to try if out!

25.description: Excellent authentic food, great staff, warm atmosphere. I will be back.Recommend the Schweinbraten. Gravy was to die for....OMG!  So good.

12.description: Edelweiss is one of the few remaining German restaurants in the Chicago area. It has an extensive beer menu, large bar area, outdoor patio (we haven't tried that because we tend to go in cold weather months). The dining room is large, and there's live entertainment of the oompah variety on weekends-polkas and old standards with a German flair.  There's a small dance floor for the Waltzers and polka aficionados.There is free self parking, but the lot is small. Street parking can be hard to find due to residential parking restrictions on the side streets. Anyway, Edelweiss has lots of special events, like Oktoberfest and Hunter's Fest (with a bunch of wild game selections in addition to the regular menu). This is how I picture a German beer hall.  Rye and pumpernickel were in the bread basket. We had goulash soup. I highly recommend this meaty, slightly spicy, warming bowl. Potato pancakes taste homemade, fresh and not greasy, served with applesauce and sour cream. The Wiener schnitzel is thin, lightly breaded, and quite good. Hubby had Jaeger schnitzel, which had a very flavorful mushroom gravy. Edelweiss no longer gives two sides with the entrees, which is disappointing. We chose red cabbage, and ordered a side of spaetzle. Honestly, the spaetzle and red cabbage are delicious and a big reason I like to dine here. I hope they'll go back to two sides with the meals. They have a small but serviceable wine list. Service is  attentive, waitress was able to provide info about wines and dishes, used plates bussed and water refilled. A few dessert selections, the strudel was flaky and very tasty. Coffee was fresh and good.

59.description: I guess this is what they call German food out west. Bland and OVERPRICED. The portions are sizeable, however, what's good about having large portions if it has no flavor.

21.description: We were very disappointed with the food and the service. We ordered Wiener schnitzel spatzel and red cabbage. The Wiener schnitzel was served with a gravy; we are accustomed to lemon wedges, only. The veal and breading seemed heavy and not pounded thin enough; could have been a commercially prepared entre, the spatzel did not taste freshly prepared and the red cabbage tasted of some unsavory spice that did not combine well with the dish. The sides seemed reheated. We returned to edelweiss as we had previously been to this restaurant in November 2014 and enjoyed the same cuisine. Yet, we were repulsed by the apple struedel; soggy, possibly frozen. We didn't even risk trying the struedel again. Server portrayed a nonchalant attitude. The bus boy was more concerned and personable.

17.description: Review number 100 for me and no surprise that it's a German restaurant. Went here with the wife and a friend this past Saturday - which turned out to be their last weekend of Oktoberfest celebrations. The place was completely packed - from the bar two deep all around to every table. It had been over 25 years since I last ate here and the place is exactly the same. They had an entertaining live band but the packed restaurant and the music made conversation a little difficult.Service was very bad because of the crowd and our server seemed to have way too many tables. He did get better as the night went on and I don't blame him at all. The tables are packed so close together that it was hard for him to get around. The beer selection on tap is very good and I spent the night enjoying half-liters of Bitburger Pils in the proper stem glass. They were cold, fresh and excellent.The food was another story and I hope it was because of the crowd but we were not impressed. We started with an order of hackepeter (steak tartare) which was fresh but not seasoned very much. This dish varies by region so I'm not knocking it because the portion was generous. Also tried an order of the potato pancakes which were small but good.For entrees we had the weiner schnitzel, rouladen and sauerbraten. None of are entrees were all that good - either too tough, too salty or too bland. The red cabbage side wasn't bad but the spaetzle was just out of a bag, boiled and slapped on the plate - no flavor or crispiness at all.And the biggest turnoff was the prices for the quality and portion sizes. I will be served two rolls of rouladen at the other German restaurants I frequent for less than the one roll cost here - and I thought it a little odd that you only get one side included with your entrée.So to sum it up, great beer served in proper glassware but mediocre and overpriced entrees.However, they have been here for over 45 years so a lot of people obviously like the place but I don't think I'll return anytime soon.

10.description: unbelievably rude owner! I came with a party of four, no one was up front to greet us, so we decided to walk in and take a look around as we had never been here before.suddenly a woman comes up behind us screaming and yelling at us because we weren't suppose to be in the restaurant.she was yelling "goodbye! goodbye!" in our faces!!! I asked who is the owner, and turns out it was her! I saw an employee behind her rolling her eyes, and looking ashamed of the owners behavior.needless to say, we left, and didn't even get a chance to eat here. and we early would have spent a few hundred dollars.businesses like this don't deserve to be in business, avoid this place at all costs. you've been warned.....

5.description: Nothing but great service and wonderful food!  When my fiance and I want to have a nice hearty meal, the first thing on my mind is Edelweiss for their liver dumpling soup and the schnitzels!  Their Edelweiss Dunkl beer is the best to go with any number of their entrees.  The staff from our server Stephanie to the hostess Dawn are always warm and engaging.  We have tried almost everything on the menu and when my brother flew in from Dubai for a business meeting, we met at Edelweiss for a family meal to catch up.  The food is similar to what my grandmother and mother cook so it always tastes like home.

3.description: I recently dined at Edelweiss on a frigid and icy Saturday evening, but the mood inside was considerably warmer.  There is a free parking lot adjacent to the restaurant, located in the embedded - within - Chicago suburb of Norridge.  Upon entering there is a pleasant bar area.  Past that are the main dining areas, and my date and I scored cozy booth seating surrounded by all things German (renderings of German cities, beer mugs, etc.).  The pleasant team of servers kept things moving along - bread basket, terrific German beers, soup, potato pancakes with applesauce and sour cream.  We ordered the Edelweiss Platter, which is a treasure trove of German foods (bratwurst, pork schnitzel, roast pork, beef rouladen, spatzle, sauerkraut, red cabbage, German potatoes, mustard and horseradish - did I miss anything?).  We topped things off with a dessert crepe filled with cinnamon ice cream, and embellished with whipped cream, chocolate sauce and bits of strawberries.  Very tasty and hearty fare!  To add to the ambiance, there was a small stage with an accordionist playing lively drinking songs.  An adorable and sharply dressed elderly couple was celebrating a birthday by dancing to the German music, showing swingin' moves that I could only dream of possessing.  Prost!

35.description: I have never bothered to review any place that didn't get 5 stars...I choose to promote the outstanding places instead of downgrading the lower tier restaurants.....this time is different....I frequent all the main German/Czech restaurants here in Chicago....BUT, have never been here even though the reviews are pretty amazing...well...Starters...Service was excellent....that gets one star all on its own...Unfortunately the food only gets one star as well....The rye bread....in the basket...was hard, stiff and did not taste "fresh"....I would say it was sitting out all day....if they make it here they should stop, and buy it instead...I ordered Pork Schnizel with Bread Dumplings and Sauerkraut....The sauerkraut was good....The pork was good (not excellent as I was so expecting) but different from what I am used to, it was thicker and not at thin as I am used to...and did not taste like the standard I was expecting....I must say I was disappointed....The BREAD dumplings were just that....I have never had dumplings like these....they were actually stuffing IMHO....wet bread....not a true dumpling like I am used to....white fluffy dumplings is what I consider a dumpling....not brownish bread with gravy....will never order those again....I am not going to promote other restaurants in their genre as that would be disrespectful....but, I do not think I will be returning....unfortunate, as this is my preferred type of restaurant.....

19.description: Edelweiss is an excellent, versatile space that has been able to please every possible age group in my circle of friends and family. The first time I came here was for my cousin's christening ten years ago. He then coincindentally returned here for his tenth birthday last year (by choice)! Also, this is a great place to take my grandmother for lunch or dinner, as it reminds her of the food of her youth. The lunch specials are excellent and cheap compared to other German restaurants in the area. While dinner prices are high, you essentially get two meals in one! I cannot remember a time that I finished my meal at Edelweiss. If you want lighter fare, eat at the bar for smaller portions and a nice bar food menu. We traveled here for my friends birthday last year and he was able to finish das boot of BBK in an hour! The beer selection is excellent. A consistent balance of lagers, marzens, weisses, & dunkels. Exactly what every German restaurant should have! I also love that they now have a cute little biergarten outside! Edelweiss is definitely worth venturing out of Chicago for. The food will not disappoint and the atmosphere is second to none!

28.description: Went here today, and really enjoyed it. Had a lovely server named Nadia. red cabbage was delicious. I had a Adult Grilled Cheese ( I know lame choice but that's another story) It was fantastic on Texas Toast with 3 different cheeses. The German Chocolate cake was AWESOME!

45.description: While I enjoyed the dinner I had here, especially the steak tar tar appetizer, I didn't appreciate the rudeness of our waitress when I tried to order a beer. I ordered a domestic beer and she said "Why don't you order one of our import beers?" Only import beer I'm familiar with is Heinekins so I asked for a Heinekin and she then insisted I order a German beer instead. Gee, lady. Why must you make a simple thing like ordering a beer complicated? It's not rocket science. Just bring me what I ask for without too many alternative suggestions and you'll get a better tip. Mmmkay!

33.description: Great German food .  we have been to many other German restaurants and this is our favorite .

43.description: Good place to sit outside...could use a bigger selection of biers...food is usually good...service can be hit or miss..all in all if it wasnt so close i would go elsewhere

2.description: There are a lot of German restaurants in Chicago and the suburbs. None quite as fun and delicious as this one. It is a little pricier than some of its competitors but it is really worth it. They have a sampler plate big enough for two, prime rib big enough for three, and other dishes that are incredible. Each entrée gets you a soup and a side. Good place for groups, nice bar on the side, and they have your standard gambling/slot machines.

18.description: Short version:  customer service - terrible!Food - greasy, not as described on the menu, not cooked properly. Paid $75 for 2 entrees, 2 soups, .5L beer. Detailed version:We came in, went to the "wait to be seated sign". 5min later the bartender saw no one was coming so she seated us. Ordered the trout and the server asked if i'd like soup or salad. Asked where it was on the menu, she pointed to soup and salad, and i ordered the gulash. The gulash was really good. I can't complain. The trout was ok-ish. The julienne vegetableS was a vegetable, and that was cucumber. Soggy. On top of sweet sour kraut (not in the menu description). And a side of 2 fried potato dumplings (no salt).  Our check was $75 because our waitress charged us for the soups, although it said on the menu that soup or salad is included with any entree, but she said that applies only for the soup of the day, which wasn't even on the menu and she didn't mention it!!!!  All in all... Not going back! PS: my husbands food wasn't cooked all the way...

41.description: Edelweiss is an excellent, versatile space that has been able to please every possible age group in my circle of friends and family. The first time I came here was for my cousin's christening ten years ago. He then coincindentally returned here for his tenth birthday last year (by choice)! Also, this is a great place to take my grandmother for lunch or dinner, as it reminds her of the food of her youth. The lunch specials are excellent and cheap compared to other German restaurants in the area. While dinner prices are high, you essentially get two meals in one! I cannot remember a time that I finished my meal at Edelweiss. If you want lighter fare, eat at the bar for smaller portions and a nice bar food menu. We traveled here for my friends birthday last year and he was able to finish das boot of BBK in an hour! The beer selection is excellent. A consistent balance of lagers, marzens, weisses, & dunkels. Exactly what every German restaurant should have! I also love that they now have a cute little biergarten outside! Edelweiss is definitely worth venturing out of Chicago for. The food will not disappoint and the atmosphere is second to none!

52.description: I had authentic German food in Hanau and this was not what I expected. Pom frits came from Walmart and the red cabbage came out of a can. Not what I expected.

50.description: It's been a few years since visiting Edelweiss and I have to admit that I'm disappointed.  I ordered the Jaegerschnitzel which was just OK.  Three pork tenderloin cutlets that were a little tough with a thin mushroom sauce that didn't have  a lot of flavor.My dining partner, who is German, ordered the breaded pork cutlets and said they were "so-so".I'm giving 3-stars based upon the excellent service and the great musical accompaniment provided by Johnny Wagner.  Johnny knows all the German standards and is a true gentleman.I'll probably be back to enjoy a couple of fine German lagers and listen to Johnny.  Maybe I'll try the appetizers next time.

4.description: Place has been here a very long time. Good German cuisine ,excellent fish fry on Fridays. Steak Tartar is the best in the entire Chicago area!   Live music on the weekends and they can handle a large group very well.

6.description: I was so disappointed in the food a friend and I had for lunch this past Wednesday.  First, we arrived around 12:30 and the place was empty of diners.  The menu did not resemble the photos they show on their website.  I ordered the Jaeger schnitzel with the spaetzel and the sauce clearly was out a packet with canned mushrooms.  Spaetzel were good though.  My friend ordered the saurbraten with a bread dumpling.  The meat was rock hard, so clearly not marinated long enough and again, the sauce that this should have braised in tasted like another package gravy.  We were both served the soup of the day, a New England clam chowder that tasted like  a creamy chicken soup with clams tossed in.  Both the carrots and potatoes were quite raw.  Neither of us finished our meal.Over the years I have been to Edelweiss many time and always had outstanding food.  They were the choice also for my Mothers memorial luncheon.  Given that they are offering Groupons, I sense that they are trying to cut corners but still encourage new business.  They failed with two customers that day.  I am not even sure that I will use the second Groupon we have.  BTW, our server and busman were fantastic!

22.description: Had a late lunch at Edelweiss to celebrate a birthday and a graduation.  I made a reservation for 9, the lady who answered the phone was really sweet and asked if we were celebrating anything, so I told her.  When we got there they had some balloons on the table, nice touch.  Service was excellent, food was great, beer was good.  They were out of Stiegl though.  They brought out two desserts with sparklers for the guests of honor.  Overall, they went above and beyond, Thank you!

15.description: 1st timer and we had a blast. Very quaint restaurant. Good food but I am not German so I could not say if it was authentic. The service was superb. We went with a group of 17. They were accommodating. Gave us a large room that seemed to be by our selves. Service was timely.Pros: fun atmosphere, fun music, live band many nights, German food, huge meals, the sampler could feed 5 people,Cons: a bit pricey, the front was very much a bar and you have to walk through to get to the restaurant.

57.description: Great outdoor area and a very legit German Feel in there! We didn't go for food, just wanted a real German beer as Oktoberfest fades away! They had 16 beers on tap and a majority were German! Bartender let us try a sip of a couple, and we opted for the Darkest Beer they had; Kostritzer! This is a local gem that we will definitely go back to! Next time, some food and a couple different brews!I'm sure you can find similar places in GermanTown, but this is a great place west of Harlem for those not wanting to fight the traffic into the Lawrence/Western area.

20.description: This place is amazing. Great food, great service and an amazing atmosphere!Special thanks to your waiter Peter who provided an outstanding service the whole evening.The only negative, if I could call it that, is the live entertainment....it could use some improvement!Other than that, it was great!

36.description: The only thing not disappointing about this restaurant was the German Chocolate cake. I ordered the halibut special. It tasted very fishy and was hard, not flaky. I was able to eat only very little of it. Maybe fish is not the thing to order in a German restaurant. My friend did not like her liver dumpling soup. My husband's veal dish was so-so. I felt the service was slow, except for the busboy who kept our water glasses always full.

14.description: Garish exterior and even more garish, brightly lit interior. But free off-street parking! Good German beer list including private label and Spaten and Kostritz. Started with potato pancakes and the ubiquitous sausage sampler. Best weisswurst I've had. Our party had Kasespatzle, Jäger and Wienerschnitzel. All excellent. And to top it off a sweet apple schnapps. Perfect service. Will certainly return.

58.description: J. Bean is what at an independent coffee shop should be! Friendly and helpful baristas, free wi-fi, sandwiches, salads, panini, and gelati; it's a great comfortable place to hang out and people take full advantage of that.Signage outside touts their coffee as one of the best cups in Chicago, the cup I had wasn't the best ever, so the jury's still out. But on a recent evening visit I had one of their unique homemade teas that they buy from a former employee and it was great! The White Pear Grape tea was super flavorful and made my Internetting here enjoyable.Many locals take advantage of J. Bean's nice atmosphere to study, play chess, Wi-fi it up- it's like a tornado whisked this place up from a Big Ten campus and plopped it down in a strange triangle intersection at Harlem and Irving Park! While neither street is a Yellow Brick Road to Oz, exploring Norridge yields some unique finds like J. Bean on Chicago's NW side!

56.description: Met here with a friend for drinks two weeks ago.I'm a huge fan of local coffee shops so I was really excited to come here because it seems that they have faded from the suburbs. I ordered a chai tea latte (I don't drink coffee) and it was great! I also ordered a vegetable panini and it was so delicious that thinking about it right now makes my mouth water.There were also plenty of tables to sit at, a few games to play, and a generally laid-back atmosphere. I think I would come here again.The reason I give this place four stars (and not five) is because I felt the two baristas behind the counter weren't friendly enough. They were cute, they did their job, and the drinks/food were good, but they didn't smile. At all. It gave me the impression that they weren't happy to be there.

29.description: I saw this place a few years ago, and have been going there for awhile. They have great coffee, cracker salad is fresh, and the american panini was so good also! I've seen this place grow in popularity over the years and I am so happy for them. I will plan to keep coming there!

42.description: Way more expensive than any chain coffee shop. $2.95 for a cookie?!?!I ordered the chai tea latte and they never asked me what kind of milk i wanted in it.  I also noticed all they used was the Oregon Chai liquid that you can buy at target. And when I drank it, it tasted watered down. and it was $3.40 for a small! WAY more expensive than starbucks. I really wanted this place to be good, but I was disappointed.

23.description: This place is super cute! Walking in, there's a lot of tables to hang out w friends and get work done at as well as a little patio for enjoying food outdoors. They had a ton of coffee choices and some wraps and paninis. I ordered the Italian with chips. The sandwich came out lukewarm and looked like it hadn't been cooked for more than a minute in the panini maker. I dont like spam much either, so I could tell before I even took a bite that it was made on the cheap. Pesto sauce was good (the best part). I hate to harp on personal appearances but there's nothing wrong with having your hair at least tied back and not looking like a hot mess at work either. I tried something new today, that's always nice....

47.description: Very delicious coffee and a nice ambiance.

8.description: Nice place, friendly and clean. Had a coffee and sandwich while I waited for tires next door.

31.description: Great coffee every time.  I was there 10 times least 6 months and the coffee was always good.  Small local coffee shop style.  Not like Starbucks with strong,  overdone mediocre coffee.  Smooth, flawrorful, with nice deep color.  One of the best in Chicago.  I know what i say.  I know most of coffee places in Logan Square,  Wicker Park,  Lincoln Park and Lakeview.  J Bean can easily compete with all of them

34.description: I just love this place, enough said. Good coffee, Nom Gelato. what more can I ask for?

16.description: New owners have now made many improvements and it is much better. New machines, new staff and service is good.

13.description: Ordered an iced chai and cafe latte. Not sure if they didn't understand or just weren't paying attention but I ended up with a hot chai. The cafe latte was tasty. Probably not going to go back because the service was subpar. Nice ambiance inside and seemed clean.

11.description: Great place! The owner is one of the last true Barista artists. If you want a heart, or olive branch or teddy bear drawn on the top of your perfectly crafted espresso drink, this is the place. They even have soy milk.  A gem in the commercialized corner of Harlem and Irving.good food.  Good coffee. Good gelato. And about 30 different flavors of syrup.

39.description: I had coffee and breakfast here with a Chicago cop friend. While we were there, no less than six other of his colleagues passed through. So there are a couple of things you can count on as a customer. It is obviously endorsed by Chicago's finest, and the chances of be mugged while sipping your latte are pretty slim.This is a small, attractive independent cafe located right across from Harlem-Irving Plaza, which has a nice menu of breakfast sandwiches, bakery treats and fancy-schmancy coffee drinks. As usual, I got my straight up black coffee, which was very rich and satisfying. I chose one of their breakfast croissant sandwiches (there are a number of these in the $3-4.00 range.) It was a generous size, but they didn't leave if long enough on the Foreman, and the cheese in the middle was cold. So you may want to order these "well-done." J. Bean is a nice little cafe if you happen to be in this area, and you would like some personalized service and good cup o' java. A good place to be served and protected.

37.description: Pistachio gelato is very good  :) and the two guys serving are very hot! Especially the smaller one..

0.description: if you're a fan of star.... or dunk .... you will not be disappointed here having a look. The more quality does not differ from the price, eateth large menu and drinks and snaks. I would recommend to anyone check this place.

38.description: Let me tell you this place has the best coffee!!  The staff if very nice too on highly recommend it if you are in the neighborhood

51.description: If this place was a chain coffeehouse, Starbucks would run away crying. I lived in the neighborhood for a few years and drove past this place countless times. A Groupon finally convinced me to go. Never did I have an iced latte this good. Perfectly sweet, smooth and with a hint of vanilla. And this wasn't even a flavored one. It was gone in like 2 minutes.I've been back several times for their Coffee Blender (that's the name of this insanely good beverage) and it's the bomb no matter who makes it. I really want to try more of their coffee creations, but I love this one so much that I never have the courage to order something else.

27.description: It's been a while since I logged on and when I did, I was greeted by a private message from a very loyal fan of this establishment who disagreed with my review and felt compelled to sling barbs. Oh, did I offend you (customer who shall remain nameless) by sharing my opinion? Sorry, let me rephrase. This is the WORST coffee I have had in my ENTIRE life, which includes diner, gas station, fast food, and instant coffee (or any underperforming brew we drink out of necessity). These are gourmet by comparison to J Bean coffee. I can't in good conscience defend a product of such low quality that mediocrity is the best thing that could happen to it.A year ago my boyfriend and I were here for an emissions test and being the junkies that we are, decided to give J Bean a try. It was a weekday, the crowd was thin and the energy was low. The woman who took our order wasn't exactly a walking ray of sunshine, but that's not the point. I ordered a latte and my boyfriend got the raspberry iced mocha latte, which was actually on the menu; he was not trying to be obnoxious. The mocha latte was cloyingly sweet (and I have a sweet tooth). It tasted like half of it was raspberry syrup. Completely undrinkable unless you wanted a migraine and a stomachache. The latte was no better. We go to coffee shops in the city at least three times a week. I know what a latte is supposed to taste like, and this was a far cry. It was watered down, lukewarm, and what faint hint of coffee was there, tasted stale. No richness of espresso or creaminess of steamed milk, just flat with a chalky aftertaste. Maybe I've been spoiled by Jackalope, Wormhole, and Metropolis. I try not to be a coffee snob, but if you want your coffee to taste like coffee, and not tepid diabetes in a cup, you probably won't like it here. I honestly think the barista was new or just made the wrong drinks... I'm from one of those generations that never throws food away, and we tossed both as soon as we left.On another note, while waiting I saw whole beans for sale, stamped with roast dates that were 3, 4, 5+ months old. I've never advertised myself as a coffee storage expert, but the person  who messaged me seemed to think it was imperative to educate me on the magic of valve-sealed technology and how it extends shelf life up to a year. I didn't remember what kind of bags they used, so I thanked him for teaching me something new and updated the review. HOWEVER I assume because I stood by my original rating, he felt that merited several choice words. Stay classy, Yelpers.

32.description: Cozy and convenient. Very nice staff. Coffee not as strong as Starbucks and not as weak as Dunkin. Perfect hot chocolate for the kids.

54.description: I absolutely love this place.. Their coffee is delicious hard for me to resist so I go there everyday :)  (so much better than Starbucks)  Food and gelato is great too.Some of the staff could be a little more friendly.

48.description: Delish coffee, tea, desserts.  Want any of the prior? Go here! You won't be disappointed.

44.description: One of the few (or possibly only?) non-chain coffee places by me.  They've got super tasty iced lattes, comfy atmosphere inside, and friendly staff.  It's a shame it's not anywhere near my route to work otherwise it would definitely be my go-to for my morning coffee.  If I'm ever up freakishly early (rather than my usual perpetual lateness, oops!), I'll totally stop in for an iced caramel latte.

24.description: This used to be one of my favorite places ... I always enjoyed great coffee and great customer service... not anymore... ever since Brian is gone this place is totally different... no spirit , no atmosphere... Last time I was in I asked guy who worked ,  how do they do without Brian and in rude way he membled something ... . I realized this must be new owner and I asked him if he was , he confirmed.   This man needs to learn a lot when it comes to customer service and the way how to treat clients... I will definitely avoid this place... he is not getting my business for sure ... and I will make sure to tell all my friends to avoid this place ...

7.description: I went in to jbean coffee today to get two cups of tea. I order, pay and I'm waiting on my tea to be made. As I'm waiting I'm watching the lady owner make my tea. As she's making it she coughs into her hand and carries on with what she's doing. I told her to redo it and she did. She hands me one cup and she's just looking at me... I told her I ordered two. These new owners are terrible and disgusting, I'm definitely not going back there again.

49.description: Come lunch time, I decided I really wanted a sandwich and needed some kind coffee to get me through the afternoon. My only options involved visiting two chains from a possible three to acquire exactly what I wanted, but I only have so much time for my lunch break; luckily I remembered this place. I've always noticed it when I run to Target, but had never stopped in. Ordered the raspberry mocha latte ($3.55) and turkey panini ($7.99). I'm not a coffee expert in the least and can only drink it in it's foofier forms, but I don't think I've ever had anything like it from the chains (Starbucks, Caribou, McDonald's). It's smooth, with little to no bitterness, and its sweetness is noticeable without being overwhelming like its melted-candy-bar-sweet chain cousins. The panini was huge (wish I'd noticed sooner that I could've ordered just a half for cheaper) and delicious.The girl who took my order didn't strike me as terribly friendly, but meh--she made me a tasty drink so that's fine. Can't wait to go back and try some other things, especially their hot caramel apple cider and maybe some gelato.

40.description: Nice people, decent coffe and food, and the world's worst wifi.Currently sitting here, enjoying a pretty good iced latte and a better than expected panini. It is a nice, comfortable coffee shop that I'd be happy to return to.That is, if it did not have the absolute slowest, worst wifi I have ever experienced. If this were some sort of anomaly, I wouldn't be so hard on them. But, after asking the staff to restart the router, they indicated they were aware of how slow the internet is, saying "Yeah, a lot of times I can't even connect to the network, so I just tell people to use the wifi network from the FedEx next door".I feel like I am on Netscape in 1998 using a 512k connection as I type this review. If you can even connect and manage to navigate anywhere, it kicks you off every few minutes. I am sitting 5 feet from the room where the router is, and there are 3 people (including myself) currently using (attempting to use) the wifi. This is the technological equivalent of serving Taster's Choice Freeze Dried Coffee.Like I said, pretty good coffee and food. But for my needs, I weigh coffee, food, and wifi equally - so 2-stars it is.

53.description: Good coffee ,place is kind of depressing

30.description: Good coffee and amazing tea selection!! Ever since my first visit iv been going there on a weekly basis.

46.description: Good coffee, Lemon Cake like Mom use to make, great staff.  Oh ya wifi to boot.  Glad I stopped in!

1.description: Caution: do not read this review if you have a weak stomach.Since becoming a member of Elite 16 I been trying to eat only at restaurants that are fun and worth writing reviews about. When I walked into J Bean Cafe in the north west side of the city I had no intention of writing a review. I wanted to grab a quick sandwich and figured it would probably be below average due to the location and aesthetic, but I truly didn't mind because I was waiting for a store in the mall to open up.  My sandwich was ready in roughly 5 minutes and got plopped down on the counter by a lady who was clearly the cook, wearing no gloves and no hair wrap at all - I mean her hair was down and all over the place it was quite disturbing.  I pretended like I didn't realize her lack of sanitation and quickly hurried back to my table. First off, I asked for bacon, egg and cheese. When I got to my table I saw that they had used turkey slices. I brought it to the cooks attention and she yelled "NO NO NO THAT IS BACON - IT IS SPECIALTY BACON". I literally laughed. Specialty bacon? this looks like Aldi brand turkey! LOL. Whatever, I was hungry and it was too early to argue, I thought to myself. I then lifted what kinda appeared to be a croissant (it was smooshed so badly the bread was literally unrecognizable) to examine the interior of the sandwich only to reveal a super curly piece of hair. Nice and calm I walked back up to register and told the lady. "excuse me, there's actually a piece of your hair in the sandwich" She looks at me...her face turns super red and takes the sandwich and starts grabbing the alleged "bacon" and wipes it with her hands and says "THERES NO HAIR!! YOU SEE, NO HAIR HERE" -- as she's wiping it down with her hands!! I was literally dying, this was both the funniest and most disgusting situations I had ever been in.  After sifting through my whole sandwich with her bare hands she then reassembles the sandwich and hands it back to me. I took it back to my table, I had been laughing so much I was almost entirely out of breath.  I had never been treated to poorly in my life, I could do nothing but laugh.  I decided to take another look at the sandwich before I walked out and of course..........I found ANOTHER hair.  This time I decided to take a pic to legitimize my review.  This lady was truly trying to convince me I was delusional and seeing mirage hairs. To be fair I was never going to come back even if this hadn't happened to me, but I strongly suggest not patronizing this business. It's sad, but very obvious the folks that own J Bean are not happy with their lives. =(

55.description: Very friendly Staff. .. Cool place.

9.description: Honestly, if I could rate this 0 stars, I ABSOLUTELY would! Wow, what an experience! I walked in to find a very unhappy woman at the counter. She looked simply miserable and like there were 30,000 other places she would rather be. I later discovered she was one of the owners - what a great way to represent your business! Surely enough, her disgusting attitude mirrored the offerings of J Bean. I figured I'd go with something simple for my first time there, so I ordered an Italian Panini and Vanilla latte with an extra shot of espresso. Before I could even finish my order, the woman cut me off and said, "The 'expresso' machine isn't working. What else do you want instead?" It kind of caught me off guard, especially since the person before me ordered a latte and it seemed to be working just fine a minute ago. Anyway, I took a moment to decide and noticed her glaring at me. Honestly, I'm not sure what I did to deserve such a nasty look, but anyway I decided I'd just try a normal old coffee. Without a response she just turned around and started pouring the coffee into a cup. The coffee was barely warm, and tasted pretty gross. I'm not even a coffee snob either, trust me, I could drink coffee from pretty much anywhere and this was like... bad. It was clearly the bottom of the barrel, so I asked if I could please have a fresher cup, and she said it was just made. I didn't bother arguing. I decided to just wait for my panini. The panini, despite being toasted, was somehow soggy. HOW is that even possible? I reluctantly brought it back up to her and said, "I think this panini is a little soggy, is that normal?" and she literally laughed and said, "It's not." Okay. Also I should mention that while I was in there I overheard one of their employees asking about getting paid, but couldn't hear their response. Curiosity got the best of me so I asked this young person about it (this is also when I found that the woman there was the owner), and they told me they're all paid cash under the table and they often withhold payment.****** Something very illegal is going on at J Bean, and everyone should know that and know how they treat their employees! *******I, for one, will not return to J Bean and urge others to do the same.

26.description: I always get the iced tuxedo. Staff is always friendly. Nothing better on a hot summer day than sitting on the patio, soaking up the sun and getting my (coffee) drink on.

25.description: With a love for coffee and experience working at Caribou Coffee for a little I started out 2014 with the mission to visit all of the coffee shops in my area. After visiting a few, I thought why not write reviews and share my thoughts on each of them. So here we are... with out any further ado let's dive right in to my unbiased review of J Bean CoffeeLocation & Ambiance:The location and ambiance are awesome! As many coffee shops I have been to, they have a great ambiance set up. Its a busy little shop with a lot of places to sit. Not necessarily somewhere I would sit and do homework, but definitely a good place to come get a cup of decent coffee. Coffee:The coffee itself was ok at best, but was a little watered down tasting. I had a skim latte, and it definitely lacked that strong coffee kick I have come to expect from a good espresso. Food:They do have a wide selection of food which was definitely nice to see! I tried the Nutella croissant, and it was very good with my coffee. I just which the coffee was strong to get a good mix with the pastry. Staff:The staff was there, but nothing special. It felt the same as any corporate Starbucks, Caribou, or anything else. Nothing special in this area. Overall, the simplest way to put this whole experience is by saying: It was ok, average, and could definitely improve.

12.description: J Bean Coffee is my favorite place for Coffee,As a Chicago Local I never understood why someone would go to a franchise for coffee when we have places like "J Bean" in Chicago that provide better coffee.Free wifi and a great place to talk, relax, or study for my exams!! After a cup from J Bean I'm immediately thrusted into energy and ready to tackle my busy lifestyle!! The staff here are friendly and always welcome me with a greeting!!Danny D.

59.description: Coffee is my crack, and this place has the good stuff. Their coffee is delicious, very strong, and the flavored syrups they use are really, really good. Even the food they serve is good. In addition to serving delicious everything, the atmosphere is pretty cool. Its a great place to hang out with some friends, chill out, and get a bite to eat (or the best coffee ever). I drink coffee constantly, and this place beats Starbucks in every way (and I LOVE Starbucks..)

21.description: My friends and I came to this cafe for the first time and had a very unpleasant experience. I ordered a cherry smoothie which was way too sweet and I couldn't have another sip. The barista named Sandra refused to adjust my drink or make another one. She said that since it's not her mistake and smoothies are pre made she won't be changing it she won't refund the $6 that I paid for the drink. It was my first and last time  here.

17.description: It's been a while since I logged on and when I did, I was greeted by a private message from a very loyal fan of this establishment who disagreed with my review and felt compelled to sling barbs. Oh, did I offend you (customer who shall remain nameless) by sharing my opinion? Sorry, let me rephrase. This is the WORST coffee I have had in my ENTIRE life, which includes diner, gas station, fast food, and instant coffee (or any underperforming brew we drink out of necessity). These are gourmet by comparison to J Bean coffee. I can't in good conscience defend a product of such low quality that mediocrity is the best thing that could happen to it.A year ago my boyfriend and I were here for an emissions test and being the junkies that we are, decided to give J Bean a try. It was a weekday, the crowd was thin and the energy was low. The woman who took our order wasn't exactly a walking ray of sunshine, but that's not the point. I ordered a latte and my boyfriend got the raspberry iced mocha latte, which was actually on the menu; he was not trying to be obnoxious. The mocha latte was cloyingly sweet (and I have a sweet tooth). It tasted like half of it was raspberry syrup. Completely undrinkable unless you wanted a migraine and a stomachache. The latte was no better. We go to coffee shops in the city at least three times a week. I know what a latte is supposed to taste like, and this was a far cry. It was watered down, lukewarm, and what faint hint of coffee was there, tasted stale. No richness of espresso or creaminess of steamed milk, just flat with a chalky aftertaste. Maybe I've been spoiled by Jackalope, Wormhole, and Metropolis. I try not to be a coffee snob, but if you want your coffee to taste like coffee, and not tepid diabetes in a cup, you probably won't like it here. I honestly think the barista was new or just made the wrong drinks... I'm from one of those generations that never throws food away, and we tossed both as soon as we left.On another note, while waiting I saw whole beans for sale, stamped with roast dates that were 3, 4, 5+ months old. I've never advertised myself as a coffee storage expert, but the person  who messaged me seemed to think it was imperative to educate me on the magic of valve-sealed technology and how it extends shelf life up to a year. I didn't remember what kind of bags they used, so I thanked him for teaching me something new and updated the review. HOWEVER I assume because I stood by my original rating, he felt that merited several choice words. Stay classy, Yelpers.

10.description: What can I say?Free Wifi and great coffee! It's a place where I can hang out and get some work done or just chat with friends. They can seriously make you any flavor of latte or coffee. Their pastries are always fresh and the staff is friendly.

5.description: This place is located directly across the HIP (Harlem Irving Plaza).  Thus, if you try to avoid the rip-off Gloria Jean Coffee inside of the food court, I would say the J Bean Coffee is a great alternative.  From we I saw today, this place is more of a coffee shop than anything else.  For food options, all I noticed were some light bakery items and gelato.  Perhaps they serve light lunch/brunch items on the weekdays; however, I'm not 100-percent sure.We ordered the large red eye coffee and a medium American-style espresso.  I honestly have to say that the red eye in Baker & Nosh is just so much better (see my B&N review if interested).  Nevertheless, red eye here in J Bean was quite decent; I just have my personal preference. On the other hand, I thought hubby's espresso was good.  They also have the Italian-style espresso in a small ceramic shot cup, if you like that style.  Overall, it's a cozy neighborhood coffee place, off the Harlem Ave. in Norridge.  Those neighborhood coffee shops are really life-savers, and you have no excuses now to visit the SB, DD, or the super-expensive GJ.

3.description: Passed some time here while wondering how my car managed to collect so many nails and require new tires. The place was pretty standard, free WiFi, tables, couches, a TV, but what is interesting is the people here. In my 40 minutes stay I saw a:Man have a loud conversation on speaker phoneMan practice playing a wooden recorderWoman paint her nails.All strange things to be doing in public, right? I was so baffled I and sipped my $4 , straight from the carton chi tea. Go for the people watching!

35.description: Seen this place while our riding bike. Thought I would give it a try this morning. Glad I did. The iced coffee was really good (ask for them to add sweetener from behind the counter). For breakfast had their Captain Jack. Egg, bacon, pepper jack cheese on a grilled croissant. Along with their hash browns (not bad, not great) total bill was under $6Defiantly going back. Want to try more menu items

19.description: This place is super cute! Walking in, there's a lot of tables to hang out w friends and get work done at as well as a little patio for enjoying food outdoors. They had a ton of coffee choices and some wraps and paninis. I ordered the Italian with chips. The sandwich came out lukewarm and looked like it hadn't been cooked for more than a minute in the panini maker. I dont like spam much either, so I could tell before I even took a bite that it was made on the cheap. Pesto sauce was good (the best part). I hate to harp on personal appearances but there's nothing wrong with having your hair at least tied back and not looking like a hot mess at work either. I tried something new today, that's always nice....

28.description: The place is nice and everything but I wish the staff would have been more helpful in answering my coffee questions because I just starting drinking coffee in Oct. 2012 so i'm like new to this whole scene. I had the cappuccino & a croissant w/netella, the croissant was delicious and the coffee was damn strong : ) I would go back if i'm in the area again.

45.description: The first moment that I step foot outside of my house, J Bean is my first destination two blocks away.  Anyone who knows me is well aware that I will not diverge from my path without an iced dirty chai in my hand.  Even when I go shopping with my grandma to Target (just across the street), she giggles at the cross lights and in Polish asks "Stopping for coffee?"  She constantly reminds me that I can make coffee at home but I know damn well that it will not be the same quality as J Beans.Every morning I walk into J Bean, Rebecca and Brenda are always welcoming.  Before I reach the counter, they are already in the process of "creating" my delicious caffeine quencher.  Recently, I was turned on to a gelato smoothie (preferably vanilla or peanut butter) spiked with espresso.  Best of both worlds I must say! Such a great summer treat! I would highly suggest having Rebecca make it, she knows all of the right portions without making it too thick.I am a STICKLER about coffee.  I will never refuse any coffee, but I am very particular about what constitutes as quality coffee.  I experience what I like to call "love at first taste".  I fall head over heels and there is no turning back until, of course, another intrigues my taste buds.  I think Starbucks and Gloria Jeans are both highly overrated and do lack the quality.  If I have an incredible sweet craving, I will only then visit my local Starbucks and purchase a large caramel frappucino.  Ten minutes into slurping up all the sugar, I feel a heart attack coming on with an instant crash. That is when I remember (and kick myself in the ass) that I should never cheat on J Bean.   I also like J Bean because it is a Mom n' Pop business.   There is no fluffy marketing that draws the loyal customers (as I).  The paninis, coffee, and gelato attract the "usuals" that I have come to know very well. Not only is it a mom n' pop establishment, which I always fully support, i LOVE to come here and sit outside during the summers whether its with friends during the evenings, or the mornings while checking my email.OM NOM NOM NOM!

33.description: I saw them on restaurant.com, so I purchased a certificate and went it to give it a try. The guy there was not very nice and said they did not take these (not sure whose fault that is). Unfortunately never got to try anything, was just upset and walked out.

43.description: J Bean is one of the better independent coffee shops in town.  I used to stop by here frequently on the way to work back in the day and still seek it out whenever I'm in the area.  Maybe not the best coffee in Chicagoland as they claim, but the quality of their lattes, iced coffee, and blended drinks far surpasses anything Starbucks and the chain coffee places serve up.  They have a good selection of tea too.  I had a iced jasmine green tea here once that was fantastic.As good as their drinks are, I think I actually enjoy their fresh basked cakes and pastries a little more.  Love the soft cinnamony coffee cake as well lemon pound cake, and plum filled crescents.  Their pastries have a wonderful homemade quality to them without being too sweet.  The perfect accompanyment to my lattes.

2.description: coffee culture is not one big mono-culture. you have your hipster spots, your chains like starbux and peets and in chicago, you have your more ethnic spots. j bean would qualify as the latter. now i know eastern european folks are not the most cheerful but to be waited on by a scowling middle aged woman who makes me feel as welcome as a bosnian in belgrade, is not what i look for in a coffeehouse. i realize i was perhaps the only square peg here as everyone else seemed to be speaking another language.as for the rest of the experience i enjoyed the strong cup of java. it tasted like intelligentsia which is a good thing. the chairs were standard uncomfortable, there was a tv on in the back and periodical music which fit the space. there looks to be a patio in back. the front view is ugly because its the side of a mall. they sold cool looking pastries and panini was on the menu board. the room was a little dark for reading, at least for middle age eyes. hey its norridge. i will not likely go back since i don't live near but coffee culture is always a good thing, even in this age of disconnection. and this place, being a little old world, was lively with conversation. in other words, a-ok
